title: coronavirus bus drivers key workers backbone of britain
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.If they didn’t go to work, neither would thousands of teachers, nurses and other key workers, writes Colin DruryDuring the first two weeks of the coronavirus lockdown, John Murphy says it felt like he was switching his phone on every morning only to find another bus driver had died.“When you’re in this profession, you’re a family,” the Unite union regional officer says today. “When someone loses their life, it hurts. The government keeps saying this pandemic is a war – well, we were being killed.”At least 28 drivers in the capital have died after being diagnosed with Covid-19. Figures for the rest of the country are difficult to confirm but it seems likely at least another dozen have similarly succumbed.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesTogether, they were young and old, veterans and relative newcomers, and from a range of&nbspbackgrounds. Some had underlying health conditions. One, Martin Egan, a driver in Bristol, had not taken a day off sick in more than six years.But what they all had in common was that, as Covid-19 swept the country in late February and early March – as it became clear the simple act of sharing an enclosed space with others was a health hazard – they kept driving. They kept turning up to do their job – because if they did not, says Murphy, “no one else would get to work either”.Teachers, he points out, “would not get to schools nurses wouldn’t get to hospitals”.NHS Nightingale hospital to stop admitting patients this week, leaked Suspend rent to help workers at risk of job loss, think tank saysBoris Johnson ‘thought it was over’, Trump saysCameron Mackintosh says theatres ‘unlikely’ to reopen this yearClarke fears fans unlikely to return to sport ‘any time soon’Staggered work times expected as part of UK lockdown exit strategyAs the country continues to wrestle with the coronavirus crisis, certain professions have stepped up to be counted in a way that has been a privilege to witness. NHS staff, delivery drivers and supermarket assistants have all shown themselves to be among a new backbone of Britain.And key among these key workers have been bus drivers and transport workers.In many ways, they have found themselves on something approximate to a front line. “But you carry on because, what’s drummed into you, is that it’s you who keeps the country moving,” says Murphy, a driver in London of 25 years before he took up his current post with Unite. “Whatever happens – terror attack, disaster, pandemic – it’s your duty to carry on.”Graham Vidler, chief executive of the Confederation of Passenger Transport, puts it another way: “Without all those working in the bus industry, the emergency network for key workers would grind to a halt.”Such workers have done all this, it’s worth adding, despite measures to protect their safety often being slow and limited. More of which shortly.For now, none of this has gone unnoticed by many of us.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailThrough the trees, this writer can see the top deck of the number 51 from his study window in Sheffield. It runs less now than it did six weeks ago. But, amid the collapsing economies and rising death figures on TV and the empty streets outside, its presence once every hour or so is a reassuring reminder that some normality still exists.The world is in crisis, perhaps, but you can still catch a First South Yorkshire from Lodge Moor up to Charnock.“It’s lovely to know you can have that effect on people just by driving your bus,” says Rebecca Holt, a staffer with Nottingham City Transport which runs 50 services a day in the East Midlands city. “People have told me what we’re doing is inspiring but it’s just my job. It’s actually quite nice having quiet roads for once.”All the same, she realised just how much she was impressing others when a van driver flashed her through a junction last week.“There were two of them in the cab,” she says. “And, as I passed through, they started clapping me. I was just like, ‘Oh wow’. I felt like royalty.”The 45-year-old is one of 173 of NCT’s 850 drivers still currently on the roads.Since the lockdown, passenger numbers have fallen across the country to around 15 per cent of pre-crisis levels. Services have been reduced accordingly with resources redirected to routes connecting high population areas to key infrastructure such as hospitals and major supermarkets.As a result, an estimated 80 per cent of the country’s 95,000 drivers have been furloughed. Stagecoach, the country’s biggest provider, has placed 55 per cent of its drivers and engineers on the government scheme.Yet the fact that many such workers were apparently willing to carry on – indeed, did carry on pre-lockdown even as infection rates soared amongst colleagues – is a sign, it might be suggested, of an unrecognised sort of heroism.“I wouldn’t call myself that,” demurs Holt, a mother-of-one who has been in what she calls her “dream job” for four years.Why did she volunteer to keep driving then, I wonder? She’s not entirely sure. Financially, she says, she would have been happy enough to take a temporary 20 per cent pay cut and have the time off.But? “I wanted to do something. I’m not a nurse. I can’t help people if they’re sick. The piece features a woman and a man pulling back to give each other a kissStudents tend to Spring Lambs at Moreton Morrell College in WarwickshireCaerphilly Castle in South Wales joins Tourism Ireland's Global Greenings campaign to mark St Patrick's DayIt was a similar motivation for Kate Russell in Leamington Spa.The 36-year-old has been a driver in the town with Stagecoach for 15 years. Her husband Dave, a fellow staffer, went on furlough to look after their two sons but she continued in her cab.“Perhaps I’m blase about the risks,” she says. “But this is my town and I wanted to carry on serving it.”Was she not worried, given the disproportionate number of drivers losing their lives, for her own heath? “Every time you hear of another driver like that, it’s devastating,” she says. “You can’t help but think about if it could happen to you. But you do what you can to stay safe and hope you’ll be OK.”She&nbspherself is happy with measures taken by companies to protect their drivers.Most are, by all accounts, now being provided with hand sanitiser and antibacterial wipes, and vehicles are deep-cleaned once a day. In London, after a concerted campaign, only the middle doors are being opened to the public. Elsewhere, holes in the plastic cab screens – which allowed drivers to better hear customers – have been filed in.“We used to call them bandit screens,” says Russell. “Now, they’re known as virus screens.”Yet, equally, there have been questions raised over whether companies – and the government – acted quickly enough.Many safety measures were not introduced until post-lockdown – when many drivers had already fallen ill with Covid-19 – while there is still no PPE provided as standard. Calls to require customers to wear face masks have gone unheeded. When some drivers blocked off the first two rows of seats on their vehicles – essentially to ensure passengers were keeping their distance – a manager at Arriva threatened disciplinary action. The company later apologised.“Safety measures are starting to appear now,” says Murphy, of Unite, again. “But if you go back to the war analogy, the enemy would have been at Hadrian’s Wall while we were still discussing defences. It was too slow, and it still doesn’t go far enough.”The union is now calling for the £60,000 life assurance payment promised to families of NHS workers who die with coronavirus to be applied to bus drivers too.“We accept that NHS staff and social care staff are in the highest category of risk,” says Bobby Morton, national officer for passenger transport. “But other key workers should be not be forgotten if the worst unfortunately happens.“What we have discovered about coronavirus is that it is an indiscriminate killer that has been responsible for the deaths of far too many bus workers who are classed as key workers, keeping the country running during this national emergency.”Back in Nottingham, it is something that Holt believes is a reasonable request – but she also has another somewhat simpler hope.“I’ve been getting more people say thank you when they get off than I’ve ever known before,” she says. “It’s lovely to hear that, it makes you feel appreciated. When all this is over, I hope that carries on.”Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: coronavirus children referrals schools open anne longfield
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Exclusive: Children's Commissioner warns school closures&nbspwill have devastating&nbsplong-term impact on children unless urgent actionSocial workers are bracing for a surge in referrals of vulnerable children when schools re-open again as abuse and neglect suffered by youngsters in their homes goes unnoticed during the coronavirus pandemic.The Children’s Commissioner said resources would be needed for councils and schools to meet the needs of thousands of pupils who are facing heightened risk&nbspduring the UK's&nbsplockdown, which she warned could have a long-term impact on both their mental wellbeing and education.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesLocal authorities warned&nbspthey would struggle&nbspto cope with the expected surge&nbspin demand without additional support from central government.Child protection referrals have plummeted by more than 50 per cent in some areas of England at the start of April, as the majority of young people&nbspare no longer coming into contact with staff such as teachers&nbspwho would normally raise protection concerns.Anne Longfield told The Independent this was leaving children effectively “invisible” during this time, adding that&nbspmore must be done to identify&nbspthose vulnerable children&nbsp– particularly those who are not currently known to children’s services – and prepare for an onslaught of&nbspnew child protection cases when schools restart.How to be productive if you have to work from home during coronavirusWhich countries around the world has coronavirus spread to?The dirty truth about washing your handsShould you be taking paracetamol or ibuprofen to treat coronavirus?What are symptoms of coronavirus – and where has it spread?Across England, more than 1.5 million children live in families where one parent or carer has a severe mental health problem, while around 830,000 live in homes where domestic abuse has taken place in the last year – a figure that is thought to be rising during lockdown, with a 25 per cent increase in calls domestic abuse helplines recorded in the five days from 30 March.Ms Longfield said: “We know a lot of vulnerable children aren’t known to the authorities and many will become more vulnerable during lockdown because of issues like domestic abuse in the home. They may have been getting by before coronavirus hit, and school would be a really important part of that, but not being in school intensifies the risk.“All the local authorities I talk to say they’re expecting and planning for a surge in referrals once schools go back. But of course, that means there will be children now who need that help, which is why during this period and as children start to return to school, it’s really important that the schools and local authorities have the bandwidth and resources behind them to try and identify where those vulnerable children are.Judith Blake, chair of the Local Government Association’s children and young people board, said councils were “very concerned” about falling referrals to children’s social care and warned&nbspit was “vital” they receive funding needed to support children and families both during the current phase of the crisis and&nbspthe recovery period.“Councils are working with their partners and communities to try to identify children who may be at risk, and putting in place plans so that if referrals spike when children return to school, they are able to ensure children and families get the right help quickly,” she added.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by email“The impact of the pandemic on some children will be far-reaching, and it will be essential that the right services are there to support them.”Government ‘needs to do more’ to protect domestic abuse victims Children’s charities are struggling more thanks to coronavirusJohn&nbspMcGowan, general secretary of the&nbspSocial Workers Union, said&nbspthe sector was not adequately funded to deal with the expected rise in referrals, adding:&nbsp“The government constantly speaks about the terrific job of the caring professions, but digging deeper reveals that the resources are still not there to enable social workers to do their jobs properly once we have a degree of normality. We are certainly not all in this together.”The Children’s Commissioner warned&nbsphundreds of thousands of pupils were also at a “complete disadvantage” due to not having access to a device on which to take part in online classes, which she said would place many at risk of never catching up, and “hugely exacerbate” the current attainment gap in schools.A third of pupils have taken part in online lessons during the coronavirus lockdown, with the figure differing considerably in different schools, accounting for around 57 per cent of privately educated children&nbspand around 19 per cent in state schools. Around 700,000 children are currently without access to a laptop or a tablet in their homes and 60,000 do not have broadband.In mid-April, the education secretary Gavin Williamson&nbspannounced&nbspa scheme to provide laptops and tablets&nbspto disadvantaged pupils to make remote education accessible during the lockdown, but Ms Longfield said this was not set to be fully in place until the end of May, leaving many children with “another month without anything”.“I’m very worried about the children already educational disadvantaged for whom this will have been a period where they’ve fallen even further behind and potentially may never catch up if they aren’t given the support they need,” she said.“We know that over the summer there’s an established understanding of learning loss for that six weeks, but for six months that's something that really starts to have a huge impact on the prospects of the child. We know poorer kids are about 18 months behind anyway, and that ide is likely to be exacerbated hugely because of this.”She called on central government to provide schools with additional funding to introduce some form of “catch-up programme” to help disadvantaged pupils return to the point they should be at academically, and for the challenge facing teachers to be recognised.The commissioner said this, along with ensuring local authorities are prepared for a surge in child protection referrals, was essential to make sure hundreds of thousands of disadvantaged&nbspchildren are not negatively impacted by the lockdown for years to come.“When I speak to some of the councils in areas already struggling economically, they’ve been saying it’s not just about now, it’s about what’s coming,” she added.“What many children are experiencing now will have long-term impact, both in terms of the trauma and anxiety, and for those who have educational disadvantage, and the fact that they will need so much more support to be able to re-enter learning in any real way.“We know the economy is going to be struggling in future. These children need every resource they can have at their disposal to be able to be resilient to what’s coming down the track as they grow up and set out on the world. One of the huge challenges for school and social services is being able to reach out to those families and keep in contact, and identify them in the first place.”The government has been approached for comment.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Help the Hungry exclusive: ‘We hope the $100,000 of food will help relieve suffering from Covid-19 but the real value of our work lies in telling people how and why pandemics emerge’A group that promotes awareness of the environmental risks of animal consumption is spending $100,000 (£80,000) distributing thousands of vegan meals to vulnerable families in London and abroad during the pandemic.Million Dollar Vegan, which challenged the Pope and Donald Trump to go vegan for a month in return for a $1m donation to charity, has teamed up with an east London charity to provide 3,800 plant-based meals to some of the area’s most needy people to spare them from hunger.The charity had already had so many applicants for food that it had been forced to turn people away.Sharing the full story, not just the headlines“Now, with our support, they can significantly increase their output, and offer an additional 3,800 meals, which will mean they can feed a lot more families and for longer,” said a spokesperson for Million Dollar Vegan (MDV).The Independent’s&nbspHelp The Hungry campaign is highlighting the UK’s hunger crisis to help those who cannot afford supplies during the coronavirus lockdown.How to support our campaignA survey by YouGov has indicated up to 350,000 people have gone hungry at times during the lockdown because there wasn’t enough food.MDV is also working in nine other countries, including Italy, where distributors are giving out 1,000 vegan meals to patients on Covid-19 wards at a Turin hospital.In Argentina, they have put together 7,000 “ethical aid” packages consisting of meals, hand sanitisers and masks, and are handing them out in the most deprived neighbourhoods of Buenos Aires.MDV was established to raise awareness of how the rearing and consumption of animals “affects the environment, both farmed and wild animals, and human health — including the global risks of zoonotic diseases and antibiotic resistance”.Timeline of viruses humans caught by interacting with animalsIt says the initiative, called #TakePandemicsOffTheMenu, combines a charitable effort with an education campaign to help the world avoid another pandemic.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailThe London meals are prepared in Hackney and delivered by bike around the area.In France, MDV is giving out 1,200 vegan bowls from a Paris restaurant to homeless people and caregivers in the city’s hospitals, and in Spain it is providing food to frontline care workers in Madrid hospitals.About 6,400 vegan meals will be provided to those in need in Mexico, and about 3,000 in Brazil. In Los Angeles, US, 700 food packages will go to homeless military veterans. Other projects are in India and Ethiopia.How we treat animals ‘still risking spreading disease’Naomi Hallum, director of the organisation, which is funded by donations, said: “We hope that the $100,000 of food we are giving will help relieve some of the suffering caused by Covid-19, but the real value of our work lies in education, in telling people how and why these pandemics emerge, in showing the destruction caused to our planet and our bodies when we eat animal products.“The coronavirus pandemic, like many others before it, is creating tragedies for families all over the world. None of us wants this to happen ever again but to prevent future outbreaks, there are some difficult lessons we must learn.“If we continue to stress wild animals by decimating their habitats and capture and cage them in markets — and if we continue to mass produce domesticated animals inside squalid factory farms and transport them long distances — there will be no avoiding a future pandemic.”T Colin Campbell, professor emeritus of nutritional biochemistry at Cornell University, New York, claimed: “A wholefoods plant-based diet can prevent, perhaps even reverse, the chronic degenerative diseases that make older iniduals more susceptible to Covid-19.”Help the hungry&nbsp|&nbspShare your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - Premium.‘Many Londoners have rediscovered the joys of walking and cycling during lockdown,’ mayor saysLondon’s parking spaces and traffic lanes could be repurposed to give more space for pedestrians and cyclists&nbspunder a new transport plan for the capital.Public transport capacity could potential run at a fifth of pre-crisis levels once coronavirus lockdown restrictions are lifted, and City Hall fears an increase in car journeys could risk the city grinding to a halt.There could be a more than 10-fold increase in cycle use and a five-fold increase in walking when coronavirus lockdown restrictions are lifted, modelling by Transport for London (TfL) has suggested.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesTo prevent an increase in the number of cars on the streets and accommodate the increase in cycle and foot traffic, the mayor of London, Sadiq Khan, has announced several steps to transform London’s road network.As well as repurposing&nbspparking spaces and traffic lanes, pavements will be widened to allow greater access to shops as they observe social distancing rules.&nbspTemporary cycle lanes will also be implemented, along with lower speed limits and the closure of some streets to traffic.Tracking the coronavirus outbreak around the world in maps and chartsWhen can we really expect coronavirus to end?Everything you need to know on supermarket delivery slotsThe dirty truth about washing your handsListen to the latest episode of The Independent Coronavirus Podcast“The capacity of our public transport will be dramatically reduced post-coronavirus as a result of the huge challenges we face around social distancing,” Mr Khan said.“Everyone who can work from home must continue to do so for some time to come.“The emergency measures included in our major strategic London Streetspace programme will help those who have to travel to work by fast-tracking the transformation of streets across our city.“Many Londoners have rediscovered the joys of walking and cycling during lockdown and, by quickly and cheaply widening pavements, creating temporary cycle lanes and closing roads to through traffic we will enable millions more people to change the way story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Cabinet office minister drops 'no compromise' stance, saying:&nbsp'If that is the price that we have to pay, then there we go'The UK may accept the “price” of tariffs on goods to strike a trade deal with the EU, Michael Gove says – as he again insisted there would be no extension to the Brexit&nbsptransition period&nbspbeyond 31 December.The charges would be “a missed opportunity”, the cabinet office minister said, but added: “If that is the price that we have to pay, then there we go.”Giving up on the demand for a “zero-tariff, zero-quota” deal could be acceptable to secure the prize of breaking free of EU rules, he told a parliamentary inquiry.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe comments come after government sources insisted the EU would have to give way to rescue a deal, attacking Brussels for refusing to accept the UK’s “sovereignty”.But Mr Gove acknowledged the UK might “end up like Canada with tariff on a possible number of goods” – billing the move as a compromise Brussels might accept.The government’s refusal to extend the transition period is recklessThe UK was “prepared to modify our ask”, to regain autonomy over “level playing field” regulations on workers and the environment. “It is one of the ways in which we would be prepared to show leg,” he said.During the evidence given to the Lords EU committee, Mr Gove also:* Insisted the EU would fail if it asked the UK for a transition extension, saying: “We think it would be in nobody’s interest. Families are being torn apart.The health secretary claimed victory in hitting his deadline to pass the threshold by the end of April, announcing that more than 122,000 tests were recorded last Thursday as drive-through centres and home testing-kits helped send numbers soaring&nbspfrom around 10,000 at the start of the month.But critics accused him of manipulating the figures after it emerged the total included around 40,000 test kits which had been sent out but not completed by that stage.And testing numbers have remained below the 100,000 level every day since the 30 April I think she might do well to take a leaf out of the shadow secretary's book in terms of tone.“I’m afraid what she said is not true. There’s been a rapid acceleration of testing offer the last few months in this country, including getting to 100,000 tests a day.“We’ve been entirely transparent on the way that that has been measured throughout, and I have confidence that the rate will continue to rise.“Currently capacity is 108,000 a day, and we are working to build that higher.“Of course, we’ve been working very hard to make the testing capacity grow as fast as possible and as more tests are available so we are able to make them available&nbsp to more people and test people right across the NHS.”The prime minister's official spokesman later said: It may be at the moment there is less demand for tests from key workers because the infection rate is stablising or falling. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Treasury insist ‘no decisions have yet been taken’ amid reports of impending end to business supportChancellor Rishi Sunak&nbspis reportedly set to announce plans to&nbsptaper off the government’s furlough scheme, which is supporting workers staying at home during the coronavirus outbreak.There are some concerns over the cost of the programme, with the latest government figures showing 6.3 million people are having up to 80 per cent&nbspof their salaries paid by the Treasury at a cost of £8bn.The Times reported that Mr Sunak will announce plans next week on how to wind down the scheme from July, with options including cutting the subsidy level and lowering the £2,500 cap on monthly payments.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesBut Treasury sources insisted that “no decisions have yet been taken” over the scheme which was introduced to prevent firms from laying off thousands of workers during the lockdown.Health secretary Matt Hancock told Sky News earlier in the day that the government must “wean off” businesses from the scheme “as the economy gets back on its feet”.Tracking the coronavirus outbreak around the world in maps and chartsWhen can we really expect coronavirus to end?Everything you need to know on supermarket delivery slotsThe dirty truth about washing your handsListen to the latest episode of The Independent Coronavirus PodcastMr Sunak has acknowledged that the current level of expenditure was not “sustainable” in the long term but promised there will be no “cliff-edge” cut-off to the scheme.Speaking to ITV News, he said the ministers were investigating ways to wind down the scheme currently due to run to the end of June in a “measured way”.Labour has called for the government to make the scheme more flexible to allow people’s gradual return to work.And the Liberal Democrats have called for a “tapered” end to the programme, with the Treasury paying 50 per cent&nbspof salaries for the first month after people return Premium.‘Human tests are expected after this summer,’ says chief executive of company developing treatmentItalian&nbspresearchers claim to have developed a vaccine that can neutralise the coronavirus in human cells.Tests carried out at Rome’s Lazzaro Spallanzani Hospital, which specialises in infectious diseases, generated antibodies in mice that work in human cells.“This is the most advanced stage of testing of a candidate vaccine created in Italy,” said&nbspLuigi Aurisicchio, chief executive of Takis, the company working on the treatment.Sharing the full story, not just the headlines“We expect this to happen in humans too.”Tracking the coronavirus outbreak around the world in maps and chartsWhen can we really expect coronavirus to end?Everything you need to know on supermarket delivery slotsThe dirty truth about washing your handsListen to the latest episode of The Independent Coronavirus Podcast“Human tests are expected after this summer,” Mr Aurisicchio said.He added:&nbsp“We are working hard for a vaccine coming from Italian research, with an all-Italian and innovative technology, tested in Italy and made available to everyone.“In order to reach this goal, we need the support of national and international institutions and partners who may help us speed up the process.”After a single vaccination, the mice developed antibodies capable of blocking the virus from infecting human cells,&nbspMr Aurisicchio claimed.He said researchers observed that five candidate vaccines generated a large number of antibodies and they then selected the two with the best results.The candidate vaccines were based on the genetic material of the “spike” DNA protein that the coronavirus uses to enter human cells.The next tests to be conducted will aim to determine title: germany coronavirus lockdown lift open museums galleries gardens shops
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Inidual states to decide on opening other institutions as infection rates declineGermany has begun relaxing the&nbsplockdown measures put in place to control the spread of coronavirus, as officials say the infection rate has been declining for “at least four weeks in a row”.Museums, galleries and gardens, as well as many shops, were allowed to reopen this week. Inidual states will decide about gradually opening universities, bars, trade fairs, theatres, cinemas, and more under certain hygiene and distancing rules.A draft document prepared by federal chancellery chief Helge Braun, seen by Reuters, also said amateur open-air sports could restart and schools should gradually reopen from 11 May.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe document will be discussed between Chancellor Angela Merkel and state premiers at a telephone conference later on Wednesday.Germany has been more successful at containing the outbreak than other big European countries, managing to keep its infection and death rate at a relatively low level. The country recorded 164,807 infections and nearly 7,000 deaths.Tracking the coronavirus outbreak around the world in maps and chartsWhen can we really expect coronavirus to end?Everything you need to know on supermarket delivery slotsThe dirty truth about washing your handsListen to the latest episode of The Independent Coronavirus PodcastCabinet minister Peter Altmaier told BBC’s Newsnight there had been “a decline in infections, for now, at least four weeks in a row”.He said the government is proceeding with caution in easing the lockdown, as having to re-impose the strict measures could have a “disastrous effect on the economy”.Berlin’s botanical gardens reopened to the public on Tuesday for the first time since mid-March. The Museum Barberini art gallery in Potsdam opened its doors on Wednesday, reassuring visitors it has a “comprehensive catalogue of protective and hygiene measures” to limit the number of visitors.The state of Bavaria announce a partial reopening for tourism later this month, with beer gardens allowed to operate on 18 May and restaurants opening a week later. Social distancing requirements must be adhered to and places must close at 10pm, said premier Markus Soeder.According to the document, federal and state governments agreed in preliminary talks that if the number of new infections rises after restrictions are eased, local restrictions should be reintroduced immediately to prevent a second outbreak.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: how long when uk lockdown end coronavirus
story: PLANS that will provide a road map out of lockdown will be announced this week by Boris Johnson.The Prime Minister, who ed to Downing Street on Sunday, April  after battling coronavirus, will address the nation this Sundayto explain how current restrictions will be lted.The Government is legally obliged to review the lockdown measures on Thursday, May .Boris Johnson has said Britain must keep going for now and is prepared to keep the country shut down into June.But, the Prime Minister is set to unveil new guidelines on Sunday, May , and said in Wednesdays PMQs that he could change the lockdown measures as soon as Monday.In the lunchtime meeting in Commons, Mr Johnson said: We have to be sure that the data is going to support our ability to do this.But that data is coming in continuously over the next few days.We will wantwe possibly can, to get going with some of these measures on Monday.This is despite the UK now having the highest death toll in Europe.Upon histo Downing Street after fighting off Covid-, the PM said Britain was now past the peak of the virus and revealed an exit plan will be unveiled this week.He said: We will be setting out comprehensive plans to explain how we can get our economy moving, how we can get our children back to school, back into childcare, and how we can travel to work and make le in the workplace safe.During his speech, its expected that:However, its understood that in some areas of the country, the restrictions could be tightened rather than eased.Its part of a whack-a-mole strategy to tackle areas where infections spike.It could lead to even stricter restrictions being imposed on areas such as care homes, prisons or whole towns.Minister Michael Gove confirmed this approach on Sunday, May , telling the daily coronavirus briefing at No: “It is important that we make clear that any approach we take is staged.However, Mr Gove acknowledged that lockdown measures will have an impact on people’s “mental and emotional well-being” - as well as economic activity.Dominic Raab extended lockdown on April  despite reports that the UK is facing its worst economic slump in historyBut Mr Johnson says he believes Britain will come charging back once the lockdown is over.Emergency measures were first announced by Mr Johnson on March .The unprecedented step was put in place in an attempt to limit the spread of coronavirus.In a televised address, the Prime Minister announced police would have the power to fine peoplethey left their homes for non-essential reasons.He said people were allowed to leave their homes for the following reasons:May : Contract tracing app began its trial in the Isle of Wight - as UK overtook Italy to have highest death toll in Europe and second globally behind USA.May : It was reported that schools are to reopen at the start of next month, with Year  kids expected to be first to , followed by Year  and  pupils, while the five tests that need passing before lockdown could be lted were revealed.May : May Day protests around the world spark fears of a Covid- resurgence.April :  Johnson hosts his first briefing since his . Promises to reveal a road map on reopening next week.April : Dominic Raab revealed the combined number of fatalities from hospitals, care homes and the wider community for the first time.April : Hancock doubles down on the  criteria to lt lockdown, expands testing capacity to care homes to protect elderly and the over s with symptoms and workers that have to leave home to go to work and are showing symptoms.April : PM Boris Johnson ed to work with a speech outside Downing StreetApril : George Eustice, the Environment Secretary, hosted the briefing alongside Professor Stephen Powis, and spoke about the UKs food supply chain. George Eustice said panic buying has stopped and , food parcels have been deliveredApril : Priti Patel said criminals are trying to exploit and capitalise during the pandemic.Priti Patel said that despite crime overall being down, the most sophisticated criminals are seeking to exploit and capitalise on the coronavirus pandemic.April : Drones are set to deliver crucial Personal Protective Equipment and medical supplies in a new Government trial. Grant Shapps has announced the scheme would begin testing next week with crucial items being delivered to the Isle of Wight.April : Matt Hancock announced that up to , people will be offered home-testing kits to help track the spread of the outbreak.April : Social distancing is likely to be needed until a vaccine is available for Covid-, according to the chief medical officer for England, Chris Whitty.April : Human trials of a vaccine developed by Oxford University were announced and will start Thursday, April . Johnson started working again, making an official call to President Trump.April : Boris Johnson tells his cabinet he is concerned lting restrictions too soon could result in a “second peak” and result in another costly lockdown. This comes shortly after the lowest UK death toll in April is announced at . There is also a new therapy being used on critically ill patients and new vaccine trials could be finished by August.April : A government adviser brought some hope, saying the UK had probably passed the first coronavirus peak. However, there was bad news for pubs that could stay closed until Christmas. Education Secretary Gavin Williamson laid out plans for  weeks of online learning but wouldnt say when schools will re-open.April : Scientists draw up top-secret traffic light system to ease Britain out of lockdown, but ministers deny it.April : Police set new guidelines in a three-page document on what reasonable excuses are to leave the house.April : Dominic Raab officially states Britain will stay in lockdown for another three weeks into May.April : Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer has urged the Government to be transparent and publish its lockdown exit strategy.April : Dominic Raab said he “doesnt expect” any changes to be made to the lockdown this week, with SAGE expected to announce the results of their review before Thursday.April : Home Secretary Priti Patel said police would be given discretionary powers to make sure people were following social distancing rules.April : Easter Bank Holiday saw warm weather descend on the UK, with the Government urging people to stay at home and save lives.April : Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab announces it is too soon to lt social distancing restrictions,  with SAGE to review the restrictions after Easter Monday.April : The Prime Minister is admitted to hospital for treatment, ten days after first displaying coronavirus symptoms on  March.April : Cops are told to tone down heavy-handed enforcement, after drones were used to spot people visiting beauty spots, and checkpoints were set up at some locationsMarch : Police get new powers, allowing them to fine Brits flouting lockdown rules £ - or £ for second-time offendersMarch : Boris Johnson announced a partial, three-week-long lockdown, telling us to stay at home to stop the spread of coronavirus. Certain businesses and venues were ordered to close, including pubs, hair and beauty salons, places of worship and campsitesPeople can drive to do a country walk but onlythe walk is longer than the drive, says new police guidance on the lockdown.It also states that you can move in with friendsyou fall out with your husband or we.The new guidance, which appears to contradict some cops’ interpretation of the law, also says people can exercise more than once a day as well as stop to rest or have lunch on a park bench provided you are on a “long” walk.Police are advising, however, that it is not reasonable to take a “short walk to a park bench, when the person remains seated for a much longer period” or drive for “a prolonged period with only brief exercise.”On May , we reported that lockdown fines could nearly double to £ for the first breach and then £, for repeat offenders.It comes after  fixed penalty notices were dished out by cops for consistent rule breakers in four weeks to April  in England and Wales.A No spokesman said: “The NHS is doing a fantastic job and the nation will want to find a way to say thank you when we have defeated this virus.” SAS hero Andy McNab added: “The award of a George Cross would show an emotional appreciation.”We are asking our readers to please sign the petition below. A letter from the Prime Minister landed on the doorsteps of  million households across the UK.In it, Mr Johnson urges people to stay at home, protect the NHS and save lives.His message follows a letter sent out by NHS England to those considered extremely vulnerable to contracting the virus.That letter warns recipients that because they have an underlying disease or health condition, they are more likely to be admitted to hospital.Theyve been told to avoid all face-to-face contact for at least twelve weeks, except from carers and healthcare workers.Italy was the first Western country to introduce widespread restrictions and has tightened them week title: why is keir starmer sir knighthood
story: And now as Labour leader, he will lead the battle to hold Prime Minister Boris Johnson and the Tory government to account.The labour leaders official title is Sir Keir Starmer, but he prefers people not to use it.He told the Ham  High newspaper that he has never liked titles.He said: When I was DPP, everyone called me director and I said, Please dont call me director, call me Keir Starmer. title: travel holiday fly coronavirus lockdown
story: THE coronavirus pandemic has put paid to our holidays this year, as airlines cancelled flights and country borders closed.But when will holidays be back on the menu  Here is all the latest advice from the government and travel experts regarding your next trip abroad.Mark Hall, Director of Product at TUI UK told Sun Online Travel that trips abroad are likely to be much later: Whilst it’s dficult to predict, we do think that autumn and winter getaways could prove more popular than ever as people still want their yearly holiday.We may see more late bookers as people cautiously search for the best deals and popular familiar destinations.Family favourite destinations such as Florida, mainland Spain and the Canaries are still top on searched destinations and we may see a demand for Caribbean holidays for winter sun at the end of  and into .It is also worth booking package holidays, as they are ATOL-protected - meaning you are coveredthe holiday does not go ahead by a refund or credit note.French President Emmanuel Macron announced in April that the strict lockdown would be extended into May.Tourists are not currently able to enter the countrytheir reason for travel is a holiday.The lockdown has been in place since mid-March, with stronger restrictions introduced on April .However, shops, schools and businesses will gradually beginning to reopen.There is some light at the end of the tunnel for trips in the summer, although officials are yet to confirm dates for when tourism will resume.The Tour de France has been postponed until August, meaning travelling around the country could be on the agenda by then.Here are some deals for later in the year.Spain is beginning to lt their lockdown measures, with outdoor walks allowed and more de-escalation measures next month regarding shops and cafes.A tourist firm in Benidorm said a spike in bookings for August and September is good news for the industry - although Brits may not be invited back so soon.President of Benidorms British Businesses Association, Karen Maling Cowles previously told Sun Online Travel: I dont personally think that we’re going to start recovering from this until June or July and even that’s maybe early.But British tourism I dont see happening until September. Because the UK is still so far behind Spain and until you have it contained, people won’t be allowed to come and have their week in Benidorm.The Balearic Islands have issued similar sentiments, with Tourism minister Iago Negueruela adding: There are countries like the United Kingdom that have taken too long to adopt containment measures and that also puts us in a dferent situation with respect to them.Some of the Greek islands, including Santorini, Crete and Kos, are yet to report any cases of coronavirus.Despite this, tourism is not expected toto the country just yet, with the flight ban being extended until mid-May.On the bright side, lockdown measures are beginning to ease and tourists could be welcomed back by Julythe virus continues to slow.Turkey is looking to resume flights by mid-May although these will be just domestic routes initially.The countrys culture and tourism minister Mehmet Nuri Ersoy said: Hopefully, we will see that tourism activities will start again during the Ramadan Feast.The Ramadan Feast, also known as Eid ul-Fitr, will be celebrated at the end of May.He added that he expected flight schedules toto normal by the end of June, with air travel likely to start with Asia, followed by Russia, the Balkans and then Europe.Tourists are also likely to need health certicates proving they dont have coronavirus to be allowed into the country.Seamus McCauley at Holiday Extras explained that booking in the future isnt necessarily a bad thing to consider, thanks to new flexible change policies.He told Sun Online Travel: Airlines are bringing forward their   winter schedule so people can book to fly then.That’s sensible for customers who are looking ahead to the end of the current crisis, and good for everyone to have something to look forward to evenit’s towards the end of the year.However, he added: But like most travel businesses we appreciate that people are cautious about making plans until the situation resolves, so we’re glad to see so much title: coronavirus women equal leadership
story: AS I have often pointed out, there are many reasons why women make good leaders.In my experience, they tend to be good collaborators because their ego is unlikely to interfere with letting other people have good ideas, and be able to voice them and take credit for them.Their emotional intelligence and empathy makes them excellent communicators.But it’s not just my view that women are good leaders. Many studies show women are more focused on building community and teams.They are more likely than men to cultivate a erse set of advisers to help them succeed. They are also more likely to follow advice.A study by management consulting firm McKinsey found that women are more people- orientated and spend more time developing and coaching other leaders in their organisation. In other words, they don’t need to reserve all the glory for themselves.There is something  at play too, though. Female leaders are more likely to be blameddecisions are unpopular or ineffective. They are questioned and second-guessed more often than men.But then Covid- entered the equation and presented world leaders with a new challenge — an invisible enemy that is highly contagious, unpredictable and deadly.This pandemic has been an unprecedented test for all concerned.And guess what  A disproportionate number of those who have passed this test — countries such as Germany, New Zealand, Iceland and Finland — have women at the helm.It is not exclusively female-led countries that are doing well, of course. But bearing in mind only seven per cent of all world leaders are women, about  per cent of countries led by women are doing well when it comes to containing Covid-. Global health experts have concluded that one thing that has led to success in tackling coronavirus is — speed.Prof Tom Bollyky, director of global health programme at US think-tank the Council on Foreign Relations, said: “Countries that have not dithered in their response, that have mobilised quickly, have done well.”New Zealand’s PM Jacinda Ardern put it simply: “Go hard and go early.”The number of Covid--related deaths is predicted to be substantially lower in areas where leaders acted sooner, even by a week, because they flattened the curve and prevented new cases.Many women acted first and made the brave decision to shut down le as we knew it, even though that was an unpopular thing to do.But it seems women leaders are listening to World Health Organisation advice and also looking at other countries for guidance.They don’t think they have all the answers but women are able to put their ego to one side and let experts guide them — something which cannot be said of Donald Trump.Incidentally, I have not seen any women leaders making unfounded or dangerous suggestions about possible cures. Can you imagine a woman leader suggesting that people inject Dettol into themselves, as dingbat Trump recently suggested Or can you imagine a woman suggesting to people that they can fight coronavirus and winthey are strong enough This pandemic is not a battle to be fought and won. It is a virus, which can affect literally anyone.No one knows how they will be affected and that bullish “fight it” approach is, in my experience, very male. Conversely, the decision to protect everyone, putting the most at risk first, is more female.It’s interesting that some male leaders seem more interested in covering up the problems. Like Donald Trump, who thinks he is an expert on everything and more fixated on garnering praise for what he has done than fixing and getting right what has not gone so well.I know I am talking in generalisations here but my experience of women is that we want to understand the mistakes and fix them, not cover them up.This pandemic has been full of dficulty and tragedy for everyone.But perhaps one good thing that will come out of it is that the world will acknowledge women deserve an equal  when it comes to leadership.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.FORMER Love Islander Montana Brown this week posted some “Instagram vs reality” pictures ­– one of her in a lacy bralette and silky shorts, the other in a cute pink PJ set.But I couldn’t help but notice that she is wearing  eyelashes and full make-up in bed – in both sets.The very idea of wearing make-up, let alone  eyelashes at the moment, is unimaginable – especially to go to sleep.A far more realistic picture of my le at present, in fact, is that I am mainly wearing pyjamas all day as well as in bed.HAS anyone  been watching Madonna’s “Quarantine Diaries” on Instagram This week she said she has coronavirus antibodies, having been tested for the virus.And her conclusion in the face of this discovery  “Tomorrow, I’m going to go for a long drive in a car and I’m going to roll down the window, and I’m going to breathe in the Covid- air,” she says.Sorry, but what  No one knows yet whether it’s possible to have coronavirus more than once and the presence of antibodies may not provide protection against the disease.This seems like a risk no one should be advocating.The bonny baby, who has already inherited his father’s hair, was named after both their grandfathers and the doctor who saved Boris’s le.A wonderful and touching gesture.Wilfred, a name not popular since the s, takes its roots from “will” and “peace”, two words very apt for these dficult times.HUGE congratulations to Gigi Hadid and Zayn Malik, who confirmed this week they are expecting a baby.I guess the lockdown baby boom has already started, which just proves that le goes on.What a beautul baby they will have.It’s great to have some good news amid the gloom.WHAT a month it’s been for Boris Johnson.For the past few weeks he has faced professional challenges far bigger than those he may have anticipated when he was first elected Prime Minister.Not only that, but he has also survived time in intensive care suffering from coronavirus. And now he is a father yet again at .I think it’s fair to say that this period will go down in his own personal history as perhaps some of the most memorable few weeks of his le.EVEN the most hardened climate change denier cannot fail to pause for thought at the before and after photos of the Solent.Aerial shots of this part of Britain’s coastline look more like pictures that have been taken in the Caribbean.The water is so blue and so clean that it looks positively tropical. In fact, it’s unrecognisable after just six weeks of lockdown.The images show how the usually murky waters of the UK coastline have been transformed, which must surely be due in part to a reduction in pollution since the coronavirus pandemic stopped leisure traffic on the Solent.But other astonishing photos from all over the world have surfaced recently too.Pollution-free images of landmarks in Delhi and Beijing, which are all too often seen shimmering under a haze of smog, are a real reminder of our role in creating pollution and also in reducing it.Imagineanother silver lining to this terrible pandemic was that we all began to understand the effects of our impact on the environment, and that we took the threat of climate change more seriously – and started to take responsibility for changing our ways.I AM as keen as the next person to regain my freedom, and for things to begin toto normal.But I cannot be the only one who gave a shudder at the thought of being allowed to choose a “bubble” of just ten family members as friends, as was hinted at by some.Can you even imagine the disputes, upsets and hurt feelings that would result all over the landyour chosen bubble had chosen another group to huddle with In fact, that rule would likely cause so much offence that we would only have ten friends left. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: china truth coronavirus truth opinion
story: AN emotional Boris Johnson described how close he came to leaving this world, just as his new baby son was about to enter it.He was near tears as he told The Sun on Sunday’s David Wooding about the moment he realised he might die. “I’m a very lucky man,” he said.Our Prime Minister was indeed lucky.He was almost killed by a hideous bug we have learned to call coronavirus. Or Covid-.It should be known unflinchingly as “Chinese flu”.This virus was born in China, covered up by China, spread worldwide by China.In American bric-a-brac shops you will see signs saying: “You break it, you own it.” Covid- is owned by China.Chinese flu has paralysed the global economy, brought poverty to whole nations and increased the risk of death and disaster across the planet from other causes.The world is in lockdown, we are wearing face masks and latex gloves, avoiding friends and family, thanks to China.To avoid perhaps even more lethal pandemics, China must be brought to book.Beijing must allow us to find out precisely how this virus escaped, whether from a leaky laboratory or its hideous wet markets in Wuhan.The first indication of coronavirus was monitored as far back as November last year.China must explain why it silenced the doctor who raised the alarm and why it allowed millions of Chinese New Year revellers to travel far and wide long after learning the disease spread from human to human.Far from addressing these issues, China is doing everything possible to wriggle off the hook.Belligerent attacks, sanctioned by the Chinese Communist Party, are levelled against any country or inidual who dares ask questions.In an extraordinary outburst, China’s ambassador to Canberra threatened to beggar the Australian economy by cutting off trade in coal and wine.Similar warnings have been heard in Germany about car exports.Their crime  To call for a transparent investigation into the origins of this lethal pandemic.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. falls to Boris Johnson, with his freshly enhanced international authority, to pick up the baton and lead the world in demanding answers.As he told ministers at his first Cabinet meeting, quoting his Chinese cash and goodwill, is also in the dock.This UN body is supposed to protect the world from perils such as coronavirus.Instead, its pro-China leaders turned a blind eye until way too late.China title: journalists coronavirus pandemic lockdown save press
story: Nonetheless, there is one indisputable need this crisis has highlighted like no other - the value of journalism. British journalism, in particular.What’s stopping you right now from falling off your perch in fits of laughter  Well, the fact that you’re currently digesting a work of journalism.This probably means that it’s an act – let’s call it that for now – which you’re used to committing on a fairly regular basis.Let’s also assume then that much of the information you gather, store and share comes from such journalistic sources.It’s likely you frequently form opinions and make decisions based on this content you consume.In fact, think really hard for a moment and try and imagine an area of your le where you haven’t been guided in some form by journalism.Buying a house, investing your savings, choosing a school, picking a holiday, deciding which box to put your cross in when you go into a polling booth .If you’re honest with yourself, you tend to make most of those decisions after you’ve digested the array of journalism available to you. And let’s also admit, disregarded too.Some of it is opinion led, some is impartial. You might not agree with all of it, and sometimes you might get ruddy cross at a paper or commentator that doesn’t chime with your world view.But together, the many erse components of British journalism create something which is profoundly valuable.The Covid- pandemic has tested our society to the limit. In the midst of a national crisis, journalists have been putting their lives at risk to keep you informed.News outlets have faithfully broadcast public health announcements – but also held our political leaders to account.The Downing Street daily conference has become a household staple, with ministerial interrogation by the press corps regularly influencing government policy.Without such probing questions and front page splashes, would you have known about the dearth of PPE or the crisis in our care homes Journalism, from local to national level, has connected communities in a way that social networks can only dream of. We have celebrated triumph in the face of adversity – and also documented tributes from the tens of thousands who have lost loved ones.But now we come to the rub.With the country under lockdown, British journalism is facing the biggest threat in its storied history.For newspapers, sales have dramatically fallen. For broadcasters and online outlets, advertising has gone through the floor even whilst audience numbers have risen.Yes, journalism joins one of many industries in financial peril right now.The work of reporters should be held up to scrutiny like any other profession. But we also need to acknowledge the sacrices its practitioners are making to keep the public informed.Everything that journalism hands to you doesn’t come for free.I’m sure that when you think about this properly, in a way you might never have done before, it really is needed more than everWe have to safeguard journalism. It is far too important to discard because it isn’t worth contemplating what the world would look likequality journalism didn’t exist.I don’t need to urge you to buy a paper or take up an online subscription, but I want you to tell everyone you meet that our sector is under a very real and present threat.I am the CEO of the Journalists’ Charity. It was founded in  by Charles Dickens and a group of parliamentary reporters – naturally in a pub.Our core mission to this day remains the same: to bring aid to journalists and their dependents who have fallen on hard times.We are stepping up to the mark, helping those in need with emergency funding and practical and emotional support.It’s why we’ve launched a #supportjournalism campaign in print and on social media.For me, a lockdown without journalists would be unthinkable.That’s why the Journalists’ Charity is standing four-square behind our industry when it needs us most. But we also need you to do your bit too.The Journalists’ Charity has been helping journalists through tough times for more than  years. title: joe wicks lockdown jamie oliver
story: RIGHT then, Joe Wicks. He’s just Jamie Oliver with a skipping rope, I assumed, before this wretched lockdown business began.A character we’ve all seen in our local park, with a pair of boxing gloves and a stopwatch, charging financial managers £ a haemorrhoid to do some sit-ups over by the ornamental lake.One of Britain’s ever-growing army of personal trainers who,he wasn’t bouncing around on YouTube every morning, would be clogging up Love Island or Ex On The Beach.That’s what I thought, anyway.Then the coronavirus hit, the local swimming pool shut, the man became a phenomenon and before I could come to my senses, Joe and his infernal timing device were beeping away in my living room, every morning, as I joined in his PE lesson. Inevitably, it didn’t last.First, Joe’s routine did me what I can only describe as “a mischief”.Then, one morning, aged , I caught sight of myself, in a picture frame, doing his “reverse frog shuffle” and thought: “Stuff this for type two diabetes. I’m out.”I’d got no closer to understanding Joe’s astonishing popularity, though, which is truly global.Over , people log in just to stare at his fairly spartan living room, every Monday to Friday.Hundreds of thousands more appear when Joe starts his  minutes of physical jerks.So, in an attempt to unlock the greatest mystery of the outbreak, I kept watching Joe and swtly came to the conclusion success was not linked to his presenting skills.But while they are helping save lives, who is there to help them The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.Because, for a host, he has a strangely distracted and chaotic air about him, with sessions regularly being interrupted by technical issues, forgetfulness and tiny daughter Indie, who charged in, dressed as Zog the dragon, on Friday.He’s not the greatest multitasker either, as Joe often demonstrates with the geography quiz he’s introduced to jolly things along.“What is the capital city of Moscow. . .   No. I mean Russia.”He also has to believe me when I tell him he’s not one of le’s natural comedians.“What’s the capital of Cuba  Fray Bentos. Nah, only joking.”The jokes need to go the same way as the viewers’ poems, in honour of Joe, which he was actually reading out loud, until modesty finally prevailed.Much safer ground is the “spot the dference” competition, which borders on insulting, when he’s merely placed his wall atlas upside down or swapped his electric guitar for a ukulele, but does hint at the drive, ambition and ego behind the man.One day he replaced the atlas with a picture of himself, the next with a picture of his “other house” in Los Angeles and suddenly the penny dropped.Joe’s loaded and his head is not just on its way to Hollywood, it’s already there, making movies and doing squat thrusts with Gwyneth and Brad.The weird thing is, in other presenters, soap actors or comedians, I’d roll my eyes at the folly.With Joe Wicks, I don’t. ’Cos I can’t help it, I quite like him.Part of that may be linked to his no-frills background and a level of personal generosity that’s way beyond most of us .But I like to think it’s got more to do with the fact that, at a time when other cynical, doom-mongering TV hosts are desperately trying to read the public mood, reinvent themselves and force their agenda on viewers, Joe Wicks is just doing what he’s always done. Sit-ups.He may not be Emily Maitlis , but he’s the irrepressible and lucky optimist telling us to get off our fat a***s when we need to hear it most.He’s temporarily indisposed at the moment, of course.A gammy arm means we Rosie is leading the workouts.But I was firmly of the opinion nothing and no one could ever stand in the way of world domination, until I tuned into Sunday night’s Diva On Lockdown and there was Gemma Collins trying to contort her mighty bulk into one of Joe’s squats while she bellowed: “I wonder how Joe Wicks would feelhe knew the GC was doing his workout ”Beaten, I’d imagine.He must never know.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.And her face is glued to the back of her head.So there will be hell to payit comes unstuck on The Real Marigold Hotel, where the only other one of the eight celebs who’s appeared looking as unearthly as Britt is former Dragons’ Den star Duncan Bannatyne, whose hair is now a “vibrant and colourful” shade of roast papaya orange. And will remain that way, until the monsoon breaks.It’s probably safe to say neither of them will be hanging around that long, though, or “retiring to India” any time soon.This is the fourth series of the BBC show and not one of the famous pensioners has given the place a second look yet.They have, however, all come home alive.So I wish the Beeb would count its lucky stars, cut the pretence, make Duncan pay for everyone’s holiday and let us all enjoy their discomfort, which is considerable and very entertaining.During the first episode: John “Nasty Nick” Altman proved as supple as Tower Bridge at his first ever yoga lesson.Paul Chuckle remained confined to barracks with the trots.Henry “Blowers” Blofeld rejected insect repellent on the grounds that: “Mosquitoes get p***edthey bite me.”And actress Susie Blake certainly didn’t hold back when the local foot doctor told her: “You have some unwanted growths.”“Yes, I have haemorrhoids.”Susie, too much inflammation.Jamie Redknapp: “We always used to turn up late but somehow we’d make it in time.Martin Keown: “Vieira was the best I ever played with. But Henry was a great player, so don’t make me choose between them.”Paul Merson: “The secret to working hard is to work hard.”ON one particularly fraught episode of her Channel  show, last week, Steph McGovern was forced to let a wasp out of her living room window, live on air.Probably halving her audience in the process.A day later it was announced the show itself was being released back into the wild, or as they put it “taking a break”.Credit for this development was being given to Steph’s long-suffering neighbours, who’d objected to the disruption the production had caused and may yet get a Bafta fellowship for their intervention.Truth be told, though, Steph’s “power hour of positivity” was more likely killed by worthiness, lack of content, technical issues and the host herself, who’s a rotten interviewer, kills every good joke stone dead, has the same set response to everythingand a terrible habit of asking exactly the wrong question.“Martin , what are you doing with all that toilet paper ” “Errr . . . ”There’s talk of a brave new dawn, in a shiny Leeds studio, later this year and when I last checked, author Marian Keyes was giving some pointed advice on how to become a good novelist: “Your first efforts will be woefully appalling. It’s like anything in le you want to be good at. Keep showing up.”Steph. Don’t.MORE now from Russell Grant’s “uncannily accurate”  predictions in December’s Mirror.“Scorpio — travel will be a great source of joy for you in April.”Yeah, April. How’d that work out for you Netflix thriller series Fauda. Channel ’s SAS: Who Dares Wins . Episode two of BBC’s Jewel Of Arabia .BBC repeating Bob Monkhouse: The Last Stand.And BBC Breakfast discovering that not only is he a war hero and charity giant, he’s a former Blankety Blank contestant as well.Cometh the hour, cometh Colonel Tom.Craig: “Arm.”Bradley Walsh: “What vowel precedes the name of more than ten dferent Apple products ”Becky: “C.”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “Which word used to describe horses of a reddish brown colour is also a type of window ”Paul: “Velux.”RE: The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “The name of what flightless bird is slang for someone who refuses to face facts ”Becky: “Kiwi.”You mock, but I shouted: “Diane Abbott.”Table, restaurant, postcode, country, Commonwealth of Nations and beyond that, his own gravitational field.Dumbest question was obviously: “Would you like dessert ”CHANNEL ’s When Will Lockdown End  The highlights.Professor Hugh Montgomery: “I don’t know.”Professor Graham Medley: “Anyone who tells you they know is lying.”Professor Peter Horby: “We just don’t know.”So in conclusion, try asking Russell Grant.RANDOM irritations: Have I Got News For You echoing to nothing but the sound of its own self-satisfied laughter.ITV numbskulls destroying Van Der Valk’s famous theme tune.Toxic hypocrite Frankie Boyle biting the Press hand that’s fed him far too well, by the looks of things.BBC’s Panorama failing to reveal every single interviewee on Has The Government Failed The NHS  was a left-wing activist.And ITV’s Joel Dommett making we Hannah the co-host of his Home Alone show.Which is a bit like Linda McCartney sharing lead vocals with Ringo. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris must ease lockdown soon
story: Boris Johnson cannot be sure the NHS would not be swamped by a second wave of infections.He has, though, taken out comprehensive insurance: The expansion of health service capacity was so huge that it can now afford to shut the new ,-bed Nightingale Hospital in London and place it on standby.The PM’s “unlockdown” decision was urgent even before the grim news of two million new benefit claims. Our formerly thriving economy is on its knees, losing billions a day. Huge numbers of jobs have been lost, many permanently.Matt Hancock’s new “track and trace” app may prove a great addition to the armoury against Covid- and we urge every Sun reader to download and use it when available. But we cannot wait for such tactics to bear fruit in the statistics.We are past the peak. Deaths are on their way down. The NHS was nowhere near being overwhelmed and that looks increasingly unlikely.The Government must not be swayed by the lockdown’s continued public support. That will evaporate once the long-term economic consequences sink in.We strongly disagree, though, with those who never thought it necessary — and make spurious comparisons of our death totals against countries of very dferent sizes and population densities.And we know what a tough call this is. But easing us imminently back to work and school, using social distancing and masks, is the right one. Yes, an NHS unable to cope would be a catastrophe.An even greater one is a prolonged lockdown . . . and a nation engulfed by bankruptcies, unemployment and poverty.WHAT a golden excuse the lockdown has been for every bossy busybody to exercise their authoritarian urges.Even so, we never imagined anyone would be mean-spirited enough to moan about the weekly clap for our ­carers — let alone for local councils to act on such petty grievances.One, however, has issued a warning to tone down the applause and Vera Lynn songs after a single complaint. Another has told a barman his sponsored singalong after the pm clap is too noisy.Do officials simply lack the backbone to tell these whingers to lump it Or do they actively enjoy sealing off ­avenues of pleasure EVEN in these grim times one announcement yesterday was too much to bear:“We have tried to make Love Island this summer, but it’s just not possible.”Our hearts are broken.What will we talk about now When will the Queen again address her disheartened nation Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: wolf of wall street wannabe
story: Jordan Homer, , totalled his flash motor just four months after buying it when he flipped over on the M near Winchester, Hants.But the trader later quipped to his , Instagram followers that at least his pricey Gucci slider flip flops had survived the crash.Jordan, from Southampton, said: “It was a second hand car worth £,, but it will be a write-off.“Surprisingly I’ve only got a small cut on my body - I probably put my hand on a bit of glass as obviously the car was upside down.He added: “A lot of people have noticed my Gucci slider which was in my boot and it slapped my face as we were flipping around and landed on my lap.“You’ve got to look at the bright side of these thingsI get upset about everything then it’s going to be an issue and people are going to be like ‘oh you’re crying’, so I thought I’d remain positive.”Jordan lost control when his car aquaplaned - something police say was caused by his use of incorrect tyres.Hampshire Constabulary said the tyres didn’t meet the minimum required tread depth and this was why his BMW flipped.Jordan claims to earn a six figure salary Forex trading and his Instagram is littered with photos of him posing with Dom Perignon champagne and Rolexes in front of iconic landmarks and idyllic beach views.Other photos show him gloating over wads of cash and parading round his Louis Vuitton shopping bags.However, followers on social media have accused him of being irresponsible and said he should have splashed his cash on safer tyres instead of designer gear.One follower called him a “donut” and advised him to invest his high salary in some driving lessons, while another branded him as a “Wolf of Wall Street wannabe” - but one that “couldn’t afford tyres for his car”.Jordan disputes that his tread depth was illegal and explained that he was out and about during lockdown to pick up a bike for exercise – not flouting social distancing rules.Jordan said: “It’s frustrating as [its been made out online to] make me seem like the young person disobeying the laws going out when social distancing - it was a completely necessary trip.“I did everything correctly and it was just unfortunate that I was in the wrong place at the wrong time.”Hants Road Policing blamed the tyres for the accident and said the vehicle lost control due to lack of grip and aquaplaned.They tweeted: Please check the inside as well as outside tread of your tyres. Especiallyyou have high power rear wheel drive car with wide wheels.This one was under the legal tread depth which will explain why its now upside down. No injuries this time thankfully.Hampshire Constabulary said Jordan’s tyres did not meet the minimum required tread depth - but he claims they were well over the limit and that he is pursuing overturning the three points on his licence with police.Jordan said: “The police said there was nobody at fault it was just one of those things - aquaplaning happens.“The tires are absolutely fine - the police measured the rest of the treads and they were all about mm worth of tread depth - which is .mm over the legal requirements.A spokesman for Hampshire Constabulary said: “We were called just before .pm to a report of a vehicle overturned on the hard shoulder of the M southbound between junctions  and  near Winchester.No injuries were reported. The driver was reported for having tyres which did not meet the minimum required tread depth.”

title: extreme nature tv host stung asian giant hornet
story: Nathaniel Coyote Peterson, the host of the YouTube show Brave Wilderness, dedicated one of his shows to feel the painful sting of Japans most notorious insect firsthand.The November  episode showed Peterson capturing the huge hornet in Japans Tottori Prefecture - what he calls one of the remote stretches of wilderness in the country - and ultimately placing it on his left forearm.Once he placed the monstrous insect on his arm with tweezers, he shouted in pain just seconds later.He said: “Oh man, wave of dizziness really quick.
