title: borders-gp-practices-stay-open-early-may-bank-holiday
story: HEALTH centres and GP practices in the Borders will remain open on Friday, despite the public holiday.The early May bank holiday is taking place on May  to coincide with VE Day.But NHS Borders wants to let people know that they will still be able to contact their health centres and practices over the phone.Patients should not attend in person unless told to do so, according to NHS Borders.Meanwhile, some community pharmacies will also remain open on Friday.For information on your local pharmacys opening hours, you can click here.The early May bank holiday usually takes place on the first Monday of the month.

title: galashiels-postman-wears-superhero-costume-round
story: A GALASHIELS postman has been wearing a superhero costume while delivering parcels.James Morley, , of Melrose, raises a chuckle on his round by donning an Iron Man suit with his high-vis vest.Mr Morley said: "If people smile or laugh because of me, thats all I wanted."The stunt has been particularly popular with older residents, according to Mr Morley.He said: "Older people are at home and havent been able to see their grandchildren and families."A lot of them wanted the photos so they could say that Iron Man delivered their post."Ive had people whove missed me asking me to come back round again so they can get photos and their children can see me through the window."But Mr Morley, based at Galashiels Delivery Office, might not be the only superhero postie in town for much longer.He told the Border : "I may have convinced colleagues to join me. Were trying to organise a day when we can all dress up."Most of my colleagues, when I said I was going to do this, they didnt believe me until I walked into the office."It is unclear whether other members of the Marvel Avengers will join Mr Morley, but some residents are already suggesting he showcase other superheroes, including Spiderman and Batman.For now, however, Mr Morley and his colleagues ndash in costume or not ndash are continuing to provide their key service in abnormal circumstances."Our job has changed drastically," Mr Morley said. "In some respects its easier, leaving parcels at the door for contactless deliveries, but its a bit like Christmas as everyones at home so theyre ordering more as they cant go out."Its like Christmas but with fewer staff, too."Were just trying our best to press on with bringing parcels and letters to people."If you know of any other key workers going above and beyond to improve peoples days during lockdown, get in touch by emailing editorial@bordertelegraph or by messaging our Facebook page at www.facebook bordertelegraph

title: whirlpool-washing-machine-recall-extended-models---full-list
story: An additional  washing machines and tumble dryers haved been recalled by Whirlpool after being deemed to be a fire risk.Heres what you need to doyou have an affected model.What hasWhirlpool said The update comes from the Whirlpool website as ofApril , which states: ldquoAs part of ongoing in-depth checks carried out by Whirlpoolrsquos safety team, we are adding  additional models to the recall.The machines are being recalled because, as Whirlpool explains:ldquoWhen the heating element in the washing machine is activated, in very rare cases a component in the door lock system can overheat, which, depending on product features, can pose a risk of fire.If you have already checked your machine due to previous recalls, you will need to check it again.The recalled washing machines were manufactured under the brands of Hotpoint and Indesit between  and .The full list of recalled modelsThese are the recalled models that have been added to the list of recalled machines by Whirlpool:WMAQB P UKWMAQB P UKWMAQB G UKWMAQB P UKWMAQF P UK.LWMAQF G UKWMAQF P UKWMAQF P UKWMAQG G UKWMAQG P UKWMAQG P UKWMAQG P UK.MWMAQG P UK.MWMAQL P UKWMAQL P UKWMAQL A UKWMAQL P UKWMAQL P UK.MWMAQL G UKWMAQL P UKWMSAQG G UKHow to checkyoursquore affectedIf you think your washing machine is affected by the recall,head to the dedicated Whirlpool recall website-washingmachinerecall.whirlpool.Yoursquoll need to enter your postcode and your model number, and the website will be able to tell youyour model is part of the recall.If it is, yoursquoll then be taken to a new page which asks you to register, which will allow Whirlpool to get in contact with you.Yoursquoll need to fill out your name, email address, phone number and home address. Yoursquoll also need to state where you bought the machine from as well.Alternatively, you can phone   .What happensmy machine is being recalled If your machine is affected by the recall, then you are advised to unplug your appliance and stop using it immediately.If you must continue using it, you should use only a cold water cycle of  degrees celsius or lower.This will stop the washing machinersquos heating element from being activated and therefore poses less of a risk.Whirlpool Vice President, Jeff Noel, said:ldquoWe will still continue to provide a free-of-charge replacement of comparable specication or in-home engineering repair to all affected customers in as safe a way as possible.ldquoWe understand that in the current climate, some customers will have health and safety concerns around our delivery partners or engineers entering their homes to carry out replacements or repairs.ldquoWe continue to follow government guidelines, with strict health and safety processes across our operations, including equipping all our delivery drivers and engineers with personal protective equipment and hand sanitiser.ldquoHowever, we will also offer customers the option of contactless delivery and removal of affected appliances.

title: melrose-shops-praise-volunteers-free-deliveries-start
story: TRADERS in Melrose have joined forces to offer free delivery to customers who are unable to leave their homes.Butcher Martin Baird, , has recruited a raft of volunteer drivers to serve products from his shop and three others.Mr Baird said customer feedback has been ldquogreat, adding: ldquoWe had nearly  deliveries today ndash itrsquos really gone bananas.Other businesses taking part in the scheme are the Country Kitchen Deli, the Premier newsagent and vegetable shop Purple Plum.Mr Baird, whose shop has been on the high street for  years, said at least  people have volunteered to deliver.ldquoI try to give them payment, but they wonrsquot accept it ndash so I just give them a bit of meat, he told the Border .Drop-offs are being made in Galashiels almost every day, said Mr Baird, with some households in Stow, Bowden and Kelso also seeking help.Mr Baird said his business has always been popular, but demand has shot up during the coronavirus lockdown.He said: ldquoIrsquove taken on a couple of youngsters just for this period andthis keeps up, I might have to employ a couple more, because I canrsquot keep working  hours a week.Ready-made meals are proving to be a major hit, Mr Baird said. Big sellers include roast beef, lasagne and sweet and sour dishes.ldquoThe amount of mince Irsquove sold is just incredible. And wersquove got a full-time pie man and hersquos just having to work his socks off, Mr Baird said, adding: ldquoWersquore the lucky ones, being busy ndash I feel for some people.In a joint statement, the four shop owners said they are ldquoincredibly thankful for the help provided by volunteers.Commending their efforts, the statement added: ldquoThey are actively committed to continuing to provide this essential doorstep service to all those who require it.

title: jack-lowden-invites-entries-earlston-high-talent-show
story: ACTOR Jack Lowden has urged pupils at Earlston High School to take part in a talent competition.The former Earlston student starred in a video on Facebook this week appealing for entries to Earlstonrsquos Got Virtual Talent.Lowden invited pupils to submit video clips of themselves doing "something really cool and extraordinary".The -second clips should be sent through Show My Homework, he said, between May  and June .Giving examples of the talent being sought, Lowden said performances may showcase cooking, acting, singing, dancing, football skills or dog routines.When entries are received, judges will whittle them down to a shortlist and then the public will vote for the winner."There will be an almighty bonanza of a prize for the person that wins," said Lowden, calling on pupils to "have some fun".Lowden, who received an Olivier Award in , has appeared in films including Dunkirkand Mary, Queen of Scots.

title: hundreds-meals-head-hardship
story: As well as providing food to children who would usually get free school meals, cooked meals are being delivered to other families in need.A number of items have been donated by local businesses and members of the community, with meals being cooked by volunteers in the Port Seton Centre.Bryan Hickman, Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council chair, said: ldquoWersquove been delivering over  things a day to the community ndash itrsquos been a big effort in every part. Volunteers are making hot food in the community centre, others are picking it up and some are delivering it. It is all being done safely.Food items have been donated by a number of local businesses, including Seton Sands Holiday Park, which gave several snack items as well as cereal, fruit and drinks.The Seaglass Inn also donated essentials, as did the local Co-op, including an extra supply of bread that had been delivered.The Port Seton gala committee, who announced last month that this yearrsquos event is postponed, also donated money that would have been spent on this yearrsquos event.The local community council, Parent Teacher Association and Chalmers Memorial Church also contributed.Bryan added: ldquoMost of those we have been delivering to have been nominated by other people.ldquoTherersquos about  or  families that receive free school meals in the area and around  OAPs, so itrsquos a lot of people.ldquoThose that we have delivered to so far have come across delighted.Donations are still welcome and will be ldquogratefully received, as will those willing to offer their services as a volunteer.A fundraising page has also been set up to help fund the effort anyone wanting to donate can do so at gofundme f yyervtcDaniel Baigrie, community development officer at Port Seton Centre, said: ldquoIn Port Seton, the local community council have been awarded funds from several local community groups to provide food for the elderly, those impacted by the crisis financially, and families supported by the Pennypit Trust.ldquoSocial Bite have also provided lunches.ldquoWith support from our volunteers, six days per week there are daily deliveries to  people, and  children are receiving weekly lunch bags and breakfast packs.ldquoWorking from the Port Seton Centre collaboratively with the councilrsquos connected communities staff, they are co-producing the daily food service which is a leline to people in the community.ldquoThere have been a number of very generous food donations from local businesses.ldquoThe community council are also managing phone calls for practical support.ldquoPort Seton Centre management committee and East Lothian Councilrsquos connected communities service are committed to working collaboratively with partner agencies to support our community in this unsettling time.ldquoIf you know someone who would benefit from support please contact us.

title: world-boxing-champion-josh-taylor-delivers-easter-eggs-east-lothian-youngsters
story: Taylor, the current IBF and WBA super lightweight champion, joined forces with the Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinner Boxes organisation who were delivering the chocolate treats to families in East Lothian.The kind-hearted pugilist, , surprised scores of children in Prestonpans, Cockenzie and Port Seton when he and his furry friend knocked on their door to hand over the free eggs.The charity took to social media to thank the undefeated boxing champ and to reveal local police officers also got in on the act with the boxer.Their message read: ldquoA huge thank you to Josh Taylor for helping us deliver Easter Eggs to the children in our community today.ldquoLots of very excited children and it was lovely to see so many smiling faces. We even got stopped by the police and thought we were in trouble but they just wanted a photo with us. Lol.ldquoSorry we could not get to every street, we did our best.One delighted customer said: ldquoA huge thank you for today. My husband died eight weeks ago and I have been struggling so much financially and mentally I contacted your wonderful project to get a chicken dinner box.ldquoI [also] asked for the Easter Bunny to visit as I knew it would be lovely for my kids ndash never did we expect Josh Taylor at the door.ldquoMy kids loved it and I have never seen them so excited or smile like this since their daddy died.ldquoThey spoke about it all day, especially my son who is a huge Josh fan ndash you have no idea the joy you have brought to this house today.Another mum said: ldquoMy two were over the moon with their eggs and a visit from the champ himself.And a delighted grandmother added: ldquoWell done guys ndash my grandson just had a visit and the look on his wee face says it all. Thank you from a grateful gran.The Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinner Boxes charity provides fresh chicken meals to people who are struggling financially in the East Lothian area.Taylor, from Prestonpans, unied the IBF and WBA super lightweight titles, as well as lting the World Boxing Super Seriesrsquo Muhammad Ali Trophy with victory over Regis Prograis in London last October.

title: couples-diamond-anniversary-party-hold-thanks-virus
story: Robert and Kay Mackie, of North Crescent, celebrated  years of marriage on April .They had originally planned a meal with  close friends and family at the Prestoungrange Gothenburg on April , but the dinner had to be postponed.Robert was born in Edinburgh on November , , and has lived in Prestonpans all his le, attending local primary and high schools.He worked in a garage and then as a miner, working in dferent pits until his retirement in .He is a keen golfer and a member of the Royal Musselburgh Golf Club.Kay was born in Canada on November , , but moved with her family to Carmichael, Lanark, when she was three or four years old.The pair met dancing at the Cavendish club in Edinburgh in May , and were engaged at Christmas the same year.They married a year later at Glencorse Church, near Penicuik.Kay worked in an office until she and Robert started their own family Sheila was born in  and Diana in .The family lived in Cockenzie for seven years before moving to Prestonpans. Robert and Kay have now lived in the same house for  years.Sheila explained why her parents had decided to marry on April .She said: ldquoMy mumrsquos only brother, Michael Robertson, was emigrating back to Canada and she wanted him at the wedding.ldquoThat was the only date they could get before he emigrated he moved back the week after and still lives there now. It was nothing to do with April Foolrsquos Day!The pair have three grandchildren, one great grandson and two step-great granddaughters. Sheilarsquos eldest son, Calum, was born in  and she said the new grandparents were soon taking on babysitting duties.Sheila said: ldquoTheyrsquore really family orientated and helped a lot with bringing the kids up. They would go to their house after school.With celebration plans now on hold, the family instead spent part of the morning waving to the happy couple from afar.Sheila said: ldquoWe went round in the morning and waved in the window. It was nice to see them theyrsquore celebrating so many years married.When asked their secret to a long and happy marriage, Sheila added: ldquoThey said to listen to each other and to not go to bed on an argument.

title: learning-lockdown-can-tough-council-admits
story: Lesley Brown, East Lothianrsquos chief education officer, encouraged such families, while agreeing it was not easy.She said: ldquoWith this being a dficult time, itrsquos important to recognise that we do not expect children and young people to always follow a typical school day, especially when parents are sometimes having to juggle other tasks such as looking after others or working from home.ldquoLearning can be carried out in a flexible way to suit a child familyrsquos inidual circumstances and,you have any questions about this or the best approach to take, please do not hesitate to contact your school.ldquoOur school staff will continue to embrace a flexible creative approach to learning and teaching, where possible maximising the use of digital technology to support learning for children who are being cared for at home.ldquoTeachers will continue posting [online] learning assignment tasks for children, including active learning opportunities which they can undertake with their families.ldquoAnyone who doesnrsquot have a phone or internet access should let their school know. They will ensure you have the ability to stay in contact with school staff and receive information and support in continuing childrenrsquos learning.The Young Scot website has useful advice and information, while BBC Bitesize is a helpful learning support resource for school-aged young people.Judith Tait, the councilrsquos chief operating officer for childrenrsquos services, added: ldquoWe recognise it is a very dficult time for families and that our children will be missing their friends and the daily interaction they get from school and clubs.ldquoWe also understand the challenges of keeping children and young people engaged in learning without the structure of the school day.ldquoWhile home will be the safest place for most young people, we realise this is not necessarily the case for everyone.ldquoThatrsquos why we are highlighting a number of people or organisations who can helpanyone feels worried, upset or unsafe ndash either for themselves or, indeed, someone .The councilrsquos advice in such circumstances is: l If possible, speak to an adult you know and trust who can listen and take action to helpl Although schools are closed, staff are still available to talk to. Email your childrsquos schoolrsquos officeyou would like to speak to someonel Contact Childline about anything ndash they are there to support children. Call  .l The website cooltalk.org provides a safe space where young people can get their questions answered accurately and without judgement. They respond to questions within  hours.l The social work department is there to help and support children and young people who are at risk of harm or donrsquot feel safe at home. Call    or   .l If you or someone you know is in immediate danger call the police on .l With schools being closed, children will be spending more time online and must be protected from cyberbullying and online grooming. Net Aware and Thinkuknow can help parents or s report abuse and have lots of information to minimise risks online.Ms Tait added: ldquoSupporting and meeting the needs of all our young people, including the most vulnerable, is always a priority for the council and our partners. In these unprecedented times, this has never been more important.

title: heavy-sound-bit-put-food-table
story: Heavy Sound, based in Tranent, has joined forces with other groups, including the townrsquos Fundamental Foods, to help get food to those in need.The social enterprise is also working alongside the Edinburgh International Conference Centre .With conferences and events at the city venue cancelled due to the coronavirus outbreak, Heavy Sound is partnering them to distribute food from the EICCrsquos kitchens to vulnerable communities in and around Edinburgh.Jordan Butler, Heavy Sound CEO, said: ldquoAlthough we canrsquot deliver our usual programmes at schools, we have resources and staff who are willing to support in whatever way they can.ldquoWe were already dealing with food poverty and isolation in our communities, something that has only been exacerbated by the pandemic.ldquoLow income, mental health, complex trauma and unemployment are factors at play, and the only silver lining has been around how people and businesses like the EICC are pulling together and collaborating in new ways to make a dference.Heavy Sound usually uses music, arts and sport to work with young people from a iety of backgrounds.Last year, the social enterprise revealed plans to work alongside the Scottish Prison Serviceand Police Scotlandrsquos Violence Reduction Unit to transform an old bus into a portable community service, complete with music production equipment, a food prep kitchen and a small hairdressing space.EICC is also working alongside FareShare during the global pandemic to help vulnerable members of the community.Marshall Dallas, EICC CEO, added: ldquoWith a signicant amount of food in our kitchens that wersquore unable to use for events, the natural thing to do was to find ways of getting it to the people who need it most just now.ldquoThe work being done by FareShare across the UK and Heavy Sound in Edinburgh and East Lothian is quite staggering their teams are working tirelessly to get food to so many communities and itrsquos a real privilege to play a part in that.

title: sisters-transform-bar-musselburghs-friendliest-pub
story: Rebecca and Victoria Fowler took over The Sportsman Bar in May last year, with a view to transforming the High Street premises.The venue has signed up to Best Bar None Scotland and Rebecca, of Tranent, felt it had made a massive dference in turning the business around.She said: ldquoHaving previously worked in The Sportsman, we knew what we were taking on but also knew it was something we could make work.ldquoThe pub had a bit of a reputation. We wanted to turn it into a safe place for people to come and enjoy a night out with a bit of banter thrown in: lsquoMusselburghrsquos friendliest pub.rsquo But we knew this wouldnrsquot happen overnight.Best Bar None Scotland aims to ensure everyone can enjoy a safe night out.The national scheme, which works through a partnership between local authorities, the Scottish Government, Police Scotland, Scottish Fire and Rescue Service and other organisations, works to reduce crime, reward excellence, and raise standards of alcohol licensed premises.Rebecca added: ldquoLicensing recommended we joined lsquoBest Bar Nonersquo and we were interested straight away since we knew we needed help to make the pub work.ldquoAfter speaking to the local co-ordinator and reading through the guidelines, we decided to use the lsquoBest Bar Nonersquo checklist as a guide to show us the safety changes we had to makethe pub was going to be a success.Rebecca and Victoria, of Wallyford, had both previously worked in the pub, which is at the junction of High Street and Newbigging.Rebecca told the Courier that promoting initiatives such as Ask Angela, designed to keep people safe from sexual assault by using a codeword to identy when they are in danger or an uncomfortable situation, had helped them achieve a silver Best Bar None award.She added: ldquoWe have now eliminated all the trouble and actively promote initiatives like lsquoAsk Angelarsquo.ldquoWe even hand out lollipops at the end of busy nights to help reduce noise.ldquoWe know that when our patrons leave the pub they are still our responsibility and need to get home safely.ldquoAll our customers now know that we operate a zerotolerance policy on trouble, including drugs.ldquoSafety has to be the top priority for any pub and, by working side by side with lsquoBest Bar Nonersquo, we know we are doing all that we can to create a friendly atmosphere for everyone who comes through the door, giving them an enjoyable and a safe night out.

title: extension-planned-school-prestonpans
story: East Lothian Council wants to add two classrooms to the east side of St Gabrielrsquos RC Primary School, in Prestonpans, as more housing being built in the town is expected to increase the school roll, which is currently , including the nursery.A spokeswoman for the local authority said: ldquoWe have submitted a planning application to alter and extend St Gabrielrsquos Primary School in Prestonpans.ldquoThe proposed work includes alterations to the nursery, increasing its space by expanding into the existing primary one classroom.ldquoAn extension will create space for a new primary one classroom and provide an additional classroom.ldquoOur five-year capital programme has allocated pound.m for the works, which are required to accommodate an increase in nursery provision through the Scottish Governmentrsquos expansion of funded early learning and childcare, as well as the need for additional classroom space.ldquoIn addition, the classroom extension will receive developersrsquo contributions from Blindwells and the nursery expansion will receive funding from the Scottish Government.Plans showing the proposed changes are now with the local authorityrsquos planning department.The school, which has been extended several times over the years, first opened its doors in .Currently, it has seven open plan classrooms, with two further nursery playrooms and other facilities.The proposed works would see two new primary school classrooms, as well as an expanded nursery space with new external canopy and the existing nursery reconfigured.The design and access statement included within the planning application notes: ldquoThe completed extension will provide state-of-the-art teaching and play facilities in line with the clientrsquos brief, as well as promoting energy efficiency through its design.ldquoThe project is to reflect the standards commensurate with a modern school facility and provide a high-quality environment that will inspire both staff and young people to achieve their full potential.The plans for the school could ultimately be decided by the local authorityrsquos planning committee, with all four members of the Preston Seton Gosford ward ndash Lachlan Bruce, Neil Gilbert, Willie Innes and Fiona OrsquoDonnell ndash part of the committee.

title: cherrytrees-nursery-youngsters-spell-message
story: Cherrytrees Nursery, on Dunbarrsquos Abbey Road, have been operating as a hub for the children of key workers during Covid-.A spokeswoman for the nursery told the Courier youngsters had been busy creating two banners .She said: ldquoWe have split into two teams working one week on and one week off."Team one and team two along with the children would just like to say a big hello to all our children and families who are not with us just now and also to everyone in Dunbar!"Be Kind, Stay Safe!

title: greggs-reveal-plan-reopen-stores-across-country
story: The Newcastle-based bakery chain said it was looking to open a small number of stores to trial how it would reopen more than , stores across the UK.The full details of how the trial will operate have not been released.Due to currentcoronaviruslockdown rules, it remainshighly likely that Greggs wouldoperate a takeaway service only with a limited number of staff working ateach store.Its understood that alimited number of stores could open by May , as part of a staggered plan to reopen fully once restrictions are lted.A spokesperson for Greggssaid on Sunday night : "We want to play our part in getting the nation back up and running again so we are planning to conduct a limited trial with volunteers to explore how we can reopen our shops with new measures in place that keep our colleagues and customers as safe as we can when we re-open at scale."McDonalds in talks to reopen storesIt comes after McDonalds said they were in talks about opening its , restaurants across the UK, according to reports.The burger chain could open for drive-thru and delivery orders as early as mid-May, the Irish Farmers Journal said.A spokesperson for McDonalds said: "Of course we are thinking about re-opening and having those conversations ndash but its unclear when that will be."

title: burger-king-greggs-kfc-nandos-mcdonalds-preparing-reopen-uk-stores
story: As of yesterday - heres what we know so far.GreggsGreggshaveconfirmed it islooking to reopen with a number of stores expected to reopen their doorsasearly as next week.The bakery chain said it was looking to open a small number of stores to trial how it would reopen more than , stores across the UK.Although the full details of how the trial will operate have not been released, it is believed a number ofNewcastlestores will be among the first to welcome customers back.But due to currentcoronaviruslockdown rules, it remainshighly likely that Greggs wouldoperate a takeaway service only with a limited number of staff working ateach store.Its understood that alimited number of stores could open by May , as part of a staggered plan to reopen fully once restrictions are lted.A spokesperson for Greggssaid on Sunday, April : "We want to play our part in getting the nation back up and running again so we are planning to conduct a limited trial with volunteers to explore how we can reopen our shops with new measures in place that keep our colleagues and customers as safe as we can when we re-open at scale."McDonaldsNo confirmed date has been revealed as to when McDonalds will , but work is going on behind the scenes to prepare for a small-but-steadyacross the country.Paul Pomroy, McDonaldrsquos CEO UK and Ireland said on Tuesday, April :"In March, we took the decision to temporarily close our restaurants in the UK and Ireland for the safety of our people and customers. Recently, we began working through a potential and limited reopening."We have been listening to our employees and customers as well as engaging with government and trade bodies to help ensure we do this responsibly, when the time is right."Restarting our business is not an easy task even when reopening in a limited capacity. We have set ourselves some key criteria for reopening, all of which take time ndash first and foremost ensuring the wellbeing of our people and creating the right environment for them toto work secondly ensuring we have enough supply of fresh produce and finally working in-step with government guidelines to ensure the safety of our customers."This week we are carrying out some operational tests to explore what our reopening might look like the restaurant where these tests take place will remain closed to the public."These tests will include exploring social distancing measures for our crew, PPE options and opening in a limited capacity."For now we remain closed, and will only reopen when we are absolutely confident we can have the right measures in place to ensure everyonersquos wellbeing.Burger KingBurger King has revealed it will open  more restaurants across the country.The move comes after the recentre-opening of six branches - all offering alimited menu to customers through delivery services including Deliveroo and Just Eat.Burger Kings chief executive Alasdair Murdoch toldThe Mail on Sunday that the next branches to open will be in Edinburgh, Aberdeen, Glasgow, Dundee and Merton in London - however theexact locations have not beenconfirmed.NandosNandorsquos has said it is reopening six of its UK restaurants for delivery from today .The peri-peri chicken chain said it will reopen the kitchens of four restaurants in London and two in Manchester to offer a delivery service through Deliveroo.It comes after Nandorsquos restarted cooking at these sites last week to serve food for NHS workers and charities.The restaurant chain said it will offer deliveries from its Camberwell, Canary Jubilee, Clink Street and Gloucester Road sites in London.It will also serve customers in Manchester from its Fallowfield and Printworks locations.Nandorsquos said it will offer a reduced delivery menu from these sites, but will not be offering eat-in or collection services.In a statement, Nandorsquos said: ldquoThe menu will be reduced to help the team maintain social distance in the kitchen and food prep areas, but never fear as the majority of Nandorsquos favourites such as peri-peri chicken wings, halloumi and peri chips will now be available to enjoy at home.ldquoEach Nandorsquos restaurant has been working under Public Health England guidelines for the past week on top of their existing health and safety procedures.ldquoEvery member of the team has been washing their hands more frequently while maintaining social distance during shts.ldquoAfter a successful trial re-opening serving meals to local good causes, they are now upping production to serve the public.The company stressed that this is the ldquofirst phase of its reopening plans but more restaurants could follow suit and open for deliveriesit is successful.Nandorsquos said that each restaurant will also continue to cook meals every sht for local charities and NHS workers.KFCKFC is set to reopen moreof its branches across the country after bringing in a new set of rules to keep staff and customers safe.The fast-foodretailer began closing its stores on March  following the governments decision to place the UK on lockdown.At that time, KFC said that it wanted to "protect the wellbeing and safety" of staff and customers, and confirmed that the temporary closures would be "until further notice."It was then revealed earlier this month that eleven stores would reopen as part of an initial phase, including two sites in Manchester.The chain is however offering a "limited menu" to customers and service is delivery-only, available through Deliveroo, Just Eat and Uber Eats for those who live near one of the restaurants.In a statement about reopening stores, KFC explained: "To do this in the right way, wersquove put new processes in place and stepped up our already stringent hygiene measures."Wersquore serving a limited menu, which means we can have a smaller kitchen team to maintain social distancing."Our teams are amazing and wersquod never ask them to come back to workthey werenrsquot comfortable, so theyrsquore ing on an opt-in basis. ldquoThe key workers across the country are doing a phenomenal job. So to say a huge thank you, these restaurants have now donated over , meals to them in partnership with Deliveroo ndash and will continue to donate  meals a week each.The full list is as follows:

title: royal-mail-stop-saturday-letter-deliveries-due-coronavirus-pandemic
story: It said it will continue to provide its letter delivery service from Monday to Friday as normal and said customers ldquoshould continue to post both letters and parcels as usual on Saturday.Royal Mail will continue to collect all mail from businesses, post offices and post boxes, it said.When will Saturday deliveries temporarily stop The will be halted from this weekend .What have Royal Mail said Shane OrsquoRiordain, managing director of marketing, regulation and corporate affairs at Royal Mail, said: ldquoOur postmen and postwomen are working very hard across the UK in challenging conditions.ldquoAs we said at the start of the coronavirus crisis, there will be some disruption to services.ldquoWe understand the importance of the postal service in keeping the UK connected at this time.ldquoWe have also listened to our hard-working colleagues who have asked us to ease the additional burden on thempossible. As a result, we are making some temporary changes to postal services.Royal Mail said it has been in dialogue with the Government and regulator Ofcom throughout the crisis and will keep the temporary change to postal arrangements under review.Reaction to the moveThe decision was criticised by the Communication Workersrsquo Union , which represents postal workers.A CWU spokesman said: ldquoWe will be seeking urgent discussions with the Government on this issue.ldquoThe reduction of the Universal Service Obligation was a key factor in our live national strike ballot.ldquoThe last thing we want to do is call strike action at this point but we will not sit back and see our membersrsquo jobs put at threat and the service to the public worsened.Last month the union called for householdsrsquo deliveries to be cut to three days a week due to coronavirus.

title: teachers-well-placed-assess-students-grades
story: The Scottish Qualications Authorityhas revealed how it aims to determine the  exam results for students due to sit them, following the suspension of normal examinations due to Covid-.And Lesley Brown, the councilrsquos chief operating officer for education, said schools were prepared to provide the evidence needed and review the results using their professional judgement.She said: ldquoWe know that the closure of schools and the cancellation of exams has caused anxiety and uncertainty for our pupils and their families. Irsquom pleased that the SQA has now confirmed its approach, and I am especially pleased to see recognition that teachers and schools are best-placed to provide a judgement on pupilsrsquo achievements.ldquoOur schools regularly monitor and track pupilsrsquo progress throughout the academic year as part of our approaches to ensuring high-quality learning, teaching and assessment. Teachersrsquo professional judgement is at the heart of our approach in Scotland and our teachers are very well placed to provide the information required by SQA.ldquoWe are working with our headteachers and school teams to make sure that our approach across East Lothian is consistent, rigorous and accurately reflects pupilsrsquo achievements. Our teachers will estimate grades using all evidence available to them, with support from their subject faculties, wider school teams and from our central education team.The SQA says its approach to awarding grades is based on safe and secure certication following public health advice and maintaining the integrity and credibility of the qualications system.Schools and colleges will be asked to provide the SQA with estimates on pupilsrsquo achievements, grades, bands and rank based on their performance so far in subject activities.This will provide an overall judgement from those the SQA describes as ldquobest placed to do so, with submissions due by May .The SQA will then check and validate the estimates it receives and look at prior assessments undertaken by pupilsthey are available ndash for example, Higher results for an Advanced Higher pupil.The schoolsrsquo previous history in estimating attainment will be considered and SQA will hold Awarding Meetings with its subject experts.Results will be delivered to learners by August  and students are encouraged to register for MySQA to receive their results by text and or email.The appeals process will remain free for schools and colleges so they can advocate on their pupilsrsquo behalfthe results do not reflect the candidatersquos achievements.The SQA has an exams QA for parents and pupils on its website, www.sqa.org.uk

title: athelstaneford-primary-school-takes-talent-show-online
story: People of all ages in the schoolrsquos catchment area took part, with entrants having five minutes to show off their talent in a video uploaded to the the internet.In total,  entries were submitted, featuring skills such as singing and sports to juggling and memory.So far, the entries have received more than , views and  hours of engagement.Stewart Brown, headteacher at Athelstaneford Primary School, said: ldquoWe are absolutely thrilled with how our online talent show has developed.ldquoTalent shows are a regular occurrence in a lot of schools. title: tesco-manager-puts-thank-notices-trolleys

title: pubs-may-limit-drinkers-three-pints-lockdown-lifted
story: Heres what you need to know.What social distancing rules could pubs face When pubs reopen for business, patrons could be limited to three drinks each before being asked to head home, in order to free up space for others to visit, a government advisor has suggested.The strict rules would also include maintaining a social distance of two metres while inside, with landlords able to issue fines to those who flout the rules.The terms are outlined in a plan by economist and government advisor, Professor Eyal Winter, who said social distancing is the key to coming out of lockdown. He also argued that the public need to know what the government has planned in terms of a lockdown exit strategy.Speaking to , he said: ldquoPeople are starving for pubs. They are an important part of British culture.ldquoOne of the most important things is to have a programme, to say, lsquoIn two weeks we will do such and such.rsquoldquoYou need to make the rules crystal clear, and to explain to the public the rationale behind each one of them.When are pubs likely to reopen Professor Winter estimated that it will take ldquoa lot of time to move back to how le was in January , but was certain that the country ldquowill get there.The Mail Online has reported that a possible exit plan could see the UK come out of lockdown in phases. The public would allegedly be allowed back into outdoor spaces first, with pubs being the last to open, as the lockdown was lted.Cabinet Office minister, Michael Gove, confirmed that areas of hospitality will be among the last to see restrictions lted.When asked whether pubs would open ldquobefore winter, Mr Gove told Sky News: ldquoThe other inference that I draw from your question, which is that areas of hospitality will be among the last to exit the lockdown - yes, that is true.What about cinemas and theatres Professor Winter has also been advising ministers on how to go about lting lockdown, and said cinemas and theatres could also reopen, but must have half empty auditoriums.Every other seat would have to be unoccupied, but he said venues could make up for the loss of money by raising ticket prices.

title: neighbours-join-forces-ensure-memorable-80th-birthday
story: James Walker, known as Jim, lives on St Margarets Road with we Valerie and celebrated his big day on Monday.Initial plans were for his daughter Morag to travel from Ireland, where she currently stays with her partner and family, and his two sons Alastair and Graeme to visit from Staffordshire and Edinburgh respectively.However, the coronavirus lockdown changed this, and meant that his family were not able to be by his side.Morag contacted Jim and Valrsquos lsquolockdown street linkrsquo for the area ndash put in place by the townrsquos resilience team ndash to askanyone could make a cake for her dadrsquos birthday.Morag said: ldquoI knew the street link lady is an active member of the community so would knowanyone was able to help.The plan snowballed from a kind neighbour making a chocolate cake to other neighbours gathering in front of Jim and Valeriersquos house to sing a socially distanced lsquoHappy Birthdayrsquo.When he heard his doorbell ring, Jim was amazed to find the chocolate cake at the front door.Neighbours from nearby Marmion Road and St Margarets Road struck up a chorus of lsquoHappy Birthdayrsquo, while Jim waved from the doorstep.He then walked to the pavement to thank everyone.ldquoItrsquos a lovely day for us to eat cake and have a cup of tea in the garden, said we Valerie.Morag said: ldquoMy dad was a bit taken aback but really appreciated the surprise. title: bridges-project-continues-vital-work-lockdown
story: Regular face-to-face sessions and group activities at the Bridges Project on Bogpark Road have been replaced with phone calls, text messages, video calls and digital work as the lockdown becomes challenging for some.Despite the dficult times as a result of the pandemic, staff have discovered ldquopositive elements of lsquoremotersquo working with young people in East Lothian and Midlothian. They have now been working from home for more than a month and have continued to support vulnerable and disadvantaged young people with ious issues which has brought about some ldquounexpected outcomes.Lynne Anderson, transitions development worker, has noticed that she is able to use her time more wisely by phoning her clients instead of driving up to an hour each way to visit them at their homes.She said: ldquoWe can use this situation to learn how things work dferently. There are opportunities to continue doing some of the activities we are doing remotely when weto normal.She is one of several staff members who have had to change the way they give support over the past weeks but it still focuses on many of the same issues. They provide help with filling out job and college applications, and provide young people with emotional support and tutoring. The response has also generally been very positive, with staff members reporting engagement levels of up to  per cent from their clients.Natasha McInninie, transitions service co-ordinator, said: ldquoI am surprised by how resilient young people are. I thought we would lose a lot of young people through this situation. However, it has actually made them engage more.Emma Scarclfe, acting chief executive, is also very pleased by how both Bridges Project staff and the young people they work with have responded to the current crisis.She said: ldquoBridges Project has adapted quickly to the unexpected situation around Covid-. Engagement continues to be extremely high and the commitment and dedication from staff to change their working practices so quickly to suit each inidual young person has been a complete triumph. Wersquore all very proud of the way young people have adapted and how resilient they are.However, there are also issues which have become ldquomagnied during the lockdown, for example, people who have dficult relationships with their family members struggle with being ldquolocked up together over such a long period. Others are affected by less income and need help with accessing food parcels, Universal Credit and other types of financial support.Many young people also need help to deal with the impact the Covid- crisis is having on their mental health. This is particularly the case for those who were already struggling with social anxiety or social isolation prior to the lockdown.Lynne said: ldquoIn the beginning, the young people thought it was fantastic. Now the reality of the lockdown is settling in and it is starting to become challenging.This trend has also been observed by personal development worker, Chris Nicol, who said: ldquoThe young people were dealing with it well during the first few weeks but have seen a downturn in their mood over the last two weeks. This is due to a combination of boredom and too much time to think but also not seeing their friends. They have realised how important those social anchors really are.He highlighted the importance of keeping young peoplersquos motivation and confidence up during these challenging times.He explained: ldquoI remind them that they need to focus on the fact that this will last for a relatively short period of their lives and things will go back to normal.Thank you for reading this story. title: family-wake-find-trapped-vandal-screws-gate-shut

title: volunteers-dishing-hundreds-hot-meals
story: The centre is working with Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council on the initiative, with staff at the centre cooking the meals.More than  volunteers at the local resilience group are helping with packing and deliveries.As many as  families are receiving hot meals or food donations, with deliveries made every day. title: goblin-ha-inspires-author-release-first-fantasy-novel
story: Goblin Hall, described as ldquoa humour-laced fantasy adventure for all the family, marks the latest chapter in the ied career of Peter Kerr.Widely known for his Snowball Oranges and Bob Burns Investigates series, he has turned his hand to another genre, with a nod towards The Goblin Harsquo, a reputedly haunted chamber that lies beneath the ruins of Yester Castle, near Gford.He said: ldquoI actually wrote the story, I think, about  years ago.ldquoIt was when my first book, Snowball Oranges, was just coming out, after waiting about  years to get published.ldquoI had an agent in London at the time and she said the way I write is very visual and I should have a go at writing a film script.ldquoI had never even read one but took her at her word and looked at the layout and general routine for laying down film scripts.ldquoAs for the The Goblin Harsquo, I had been to the old castle, with one of my pals who lived in Gford, when we were both about  way back in the s.ldquoThe place itself was not much to see, except peeking into the underground chamber, which inspired me.ldquoIt was bloody frightening and a very spooky place ndash it stuck in my mind.It was only two years ago, when transferring stories to a new computer, that Peter revisited his original film script and set about creating the novel.The legend of the Goblin Harsquo states that Sir Hugo de Gfard, known as the Wizard of Yester, made a pact with the devil to raise a magical army, who he used to carry out his will.Peterrsquos new tale, which is available from Amazon, features an evil sorcerer called Zorn, who has lured two young children into his subterranean lair as bait to ensnare his arch rival, a wizard called Mungo.It is up to the lovable but dippy old wizard to help free the youngsters from Zornrsquos clutches.The author, of Haddingtonrsquos Chalybeate, said feedback about the story was ldquoquite encouraging.That came despite the -year-old making an interesting revelation to the Courier. He said: ldquoI honestly donrsquot think I have ever read a fantasy novel!ldquoThat same literary agent, when she was trying to get a publisher for Snowball Oranges, told me detective novels were always popular.ldquoIrsquove never read one of those either and she said, lsquowell,you write one it will be original, evenit is rubbishrsquo.ldquoThat was the same attitude I took towards writing the fantasy novel.ldquoThe reaction so far has been quite encouraging.Peter was in popular s jazz band the Clyde Valley Stompers, who charted with Peter and The Wolf and were supported by The Beatles before the Fab Four made it big.Later, Peter produced more than  albums ndash including the Royal Scots Dragoon Guardsrsquo international chart-topper Amazing Grace ndash the biggest-selling instrumental of all time with  million sales.Thank you for reading this story. title: lockdown-birthday-proves-one-remember-neighbours-wave
story: Ian Millar has been recovering from heart bypass surgery at his home in Haddington and, under lockdown guidelines, has been staying in.However, daughter Susan was determined to make sure his landmark birthday did not go unmarked, and decorated his car with balloons and a poster asking passers-by to wave to her dad.And, last Friday, lots of families out for their daily walk stopped to do just that.Susan said: ldquoDad has not been able to get out of the house and is recovering from his operation so I wanted to surprise him. title: thirty-seven-new-homes-given-green-light-dunbar
story: Thirty-seven new homes on the outskirts of Dunbar were given the go ahead, despite concerns lodged by the community council.The statutory consultee contacted East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department when Harrison Hunt Ltd and Hallhill Developments Ltdrsquos plans were submitted in November last year.The scheme, which was approved at the beginning of the month, is a mix of three and four-bedroom homes on the south-west corner of the Hallhill area.Community councillors outlined  concerns with the proposals, including the layout and footpath provision, as well as the effects on habitat and the increased demand on education provision in the town.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the group, said it could be ldquoincredibly depressing to feel the views of the community council were not being given full consideration.She said: ldquoAll the comments we continue to make about connectivity, safe routes to school, play spaces, maximising potential for ecological building... all of that and we just feel asit is ignored.ldquoIt will not stop us making the comments but it does sometimes feel aswe are whistling in the wind.The development, to the west of Yosemite Park and Fall Avenue, will consist of: four three-bedroom terraced homes  three-bedroom detached and semi-detached properties  four-bedroom detached homes and four four-bedroom semi-detached houses.The proposals were approved by the local authorityrsquos planning department, which said the homes would be ldquoappropriate to their location given their height, size and scale.The planning officer added: ldquoThe proposed residential development would provide an attractive residential environment. The residential units are shown to be laid out in such a way that adheres to the normally accepted privacy and amenity criteria on overlooking and overshadowing, whilst affording the future occupants of the residential units an appropriate level of privacy and residential amenity.Access to the new development would come from Fall Avenue and James Kirk Way.A design and access statement included within the planning application notes meetings had taken place with ious local authority departments in a bid to address ious design requirements.It concludes: ldquoOverall, it is considered that the final design creates a well-considered, proportionate design that responds to the site constraints and the nearby area to create a positive design solution.ldquoThe result is a development that will make a positive contribution socially, economically and aesthetically to the area and enhance the amenity of existing and future residents within this area.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council stressed they ldquowelcomed comments from community councils.She said: ldquoIn this case, we consulted the community council back in December, and they submitted a response detailing a number of concerns.ldquoThese included concerns over house type and layout, increased vehicle movement and parking space provision.ldquoWhilst we understand that consultees may be frustrated when planning authorities do not always agree with their comments, we must balance these comments against the other material considerations of each case.ldquoIn the case of the Hallhill application, our conclusion was that, subject to the imposition of conditions, the proposed development was acceptable.Thank you for reading this story. title: grey-squirrels-targeting-dirleton-bowling-clubs-clubhouse
story: Dirleton Bowling Club, which dates back almost  years, is aiming to refurbish its clubhouse because of the troublesome creatures.A new roof would be included in the works, which are being weighed up by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department.Improvements to the footpath would also be included but a design and access statement in the planning application highlights that it is squirrels which are the problem.It reads: ldquoThe catalyst for this improvement project is the extensive ongoing damage to the existing clubhouse roof caused by grey squirrels nesting in the roof during the past three winters.ldquoThey penetrate between the pantiles and nest underneath them, gnawing their way through to the clubroom itself.The bowling club has been part of the social fabric of the village for  years, with the clubhouse and steps to the bowling green built in .The design and access statement also spells out what the bowling club means to the village and the potential consequencesthe proposals are not given the go ahead.ldquoIt is the only village sports club providing exercise and social, intergenerational contact through sport, and the only village team representing the Dirleton community, reads the nine-page document.ldquoIf the practical issues set out below mean that the clubhouse becomes unusable, then the club will be unable to compete in the bowling leagues.ldquoThe expectation of visiting teams is now much higher than it used to be, and clubs such as North Berwick, Aberlady, Stenton and Gullane all have new improved facilities.ldquoThe clubhouse is dark and damp and the roof sarking boards are being damaged and holed by grey squirrels.ldquoThere is no lighting to the path, which is also muddy and slippery because water pours onto it title: delivering-hope-cheer-supplies-couriers-community
story: Couriers are being delivered to  North Berwick residents who are unable to leave their homes due to coronavirus shielding thanks to a new support fund to help people in the town.While in Haddington, the townrsquos Rotary Club this week purchased  copies to deliver to residents in lockdown in their town.North Berwick Community Council chairman Judy Lockhart said the initiative was aimed, primarily, at residents who did not have access to the internet but wanted to find out what was happening in the area and to get vital information about how to get help and support.Copies of the paper are delivered by North Berwick Community Emergency Resilience Group volunteers to housing for older people, care homes, the day centre and people who were not able to get out of their homes.ldquoWe want to ensure that everyone knows whatrsquos going on and how to get help and support at a very dficult time, said Judy.ldquoThe Courier is a leline. We know local newsagents deliver to many people, but this short-term scheme will ensure that people who donrsquot get a delivery or who canrsquot afford a Courier are kept in touch. It is also important to support the Courier during this periodwe are to see it survive. Newspapers are essential for local democracy and the Courier regularly reports on issues we discuss at the council.One of the volunteers who deliver the newspaper is Susan Taylor ndash in her beloved Dolly CV which goes by the name of Myrtille.Susan, whose day job is working for the Church of Scotland as an executive assistant, is one of the team of resilience group volunteers picking up prescriptions for residents.ldquoI volunteered because I really feel for those people in our community who are at risk and isolated due to the Covid- outbreak, she said. ldquoI have met some lovely people so far and am glad I am in a position to help.The project is paid for through the townrsquos Community Emergency Resilience Fund ndash which comprises public donations, funding from North Berwick Community Council and the North Berwick Trust.Rotary Haddington was always looking for ways to support its community, said club president Malcolm Collins.ldquoOur idea to bulk-buy and distribute copies of the Courier to the elderly and vulnerable originated from one of our members who was quick to realise that a signicant number of such people would soon begin to feel isolated and lose touch with what was happening locallythey were unable to get out and buy a copy, he added.ldquoAs well as providing local news, the initiative shown by the Courier by including pages of extra puzzles in the paper was also thought to be useful to help keep folk entertained during these dficult times.ldquoWe have now taken this idea forward and arranged to bulk-buy copies of the Courier each week in advance, have them delivered to a central hub and then arranged for them to be distributed to other locations where they can be made available to those in need e.g. Our Community Kitchen, title: yummikeys-aiming-spread-joy-sunflower-seeds
story: Elspeth Fawcett set up Yummikeys three years ago, an eco-friendly toy company that makes stainless steel sensory toys for babies.Elspeth has started adding sunflower seeds to all of her orders for people to plant inside or in their gardens.The -year-old mum of three is also donating five per cent of all profits directly to For the Love of Scrubs, an initiative set up to provide scrubs to frontline NHS staff during the coronavirus pandemic, and Womenrsquos Aid.Elspeth said: ldquoI really want to do something to help spread happiness and joy over the coming weeks as I appreciate that this is such a dficult time for everyone.ldquoIrsquove chosen to add sunflower seeds to all orders as this is something that everyone can enjoy, even those who are not fortunate enough to have gardens. I love seeing all of the rainbows in peoples windows but we can only enjoy these for the short time that we are out exercising each day, so my intention is for these sunflowers to be enjoyed for the rest of the time we are at home or in our gardens.On donating her profits she added: ldquoIrsquom a small business working hard to overcome the challenges that coronavirus has placed on all of our lives, but I feel this is really the right thing to do as my donation will hopefully help those who need it most right now.Thank you for reading this story.
